Overall, a very impressive piece.

A rare piece of fiction about an indie musician that doesn't feel fake.

f you like your horror funny and aren't too squeamish -- say, you're a big fan of Re-Animator or ... Evil Dead 2 -- then Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 will be right up your alley.

Mindlessly entertaining, slick and stylishly creepy albeit deficient in real surprises and visceral scares. It's a cut above the recent slew of horror remakes.
Fleetingly amusing, charming and harmless with a terrific cast, but often meanders, lacks bite, and unevenly juggles comedy, drama and romance.

Never overstays its welcome and manages to be curiously engaging, heartfelt, funny and amusing at times, but without much-needed insight, it leaves you feeling unenlightened and slightly underwhelmed.

Quietly absorbing, mature and unpretentious with well-nuanced performances and lush cinematography.
Sporadically creepy, stylish and initially suspenseful, but ultimately unimaginative, asinine and deficient in clever surprises and palpable thrills.
Frustratingly elliptical and slightly convoluted, but unconventionally and intriguingly structured enough to maintain suspense amidst its tangled web of blurred realities.
A well-researched, vital, provocative and inspirational documentary that's equally informative, captivating and moving.
movie_title: Have You Heard from Johannesburg?: Apartheid and the Club of the West (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A wildly entertaining, funny, suspenseful and invigorating documentary regardless of whether you're a fan of street art or not.
Genuinely poignant, compelling and unflinchingly honest with just the right balance of dramatic tension and comic relief
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An exhilarating, brilliant and outrageously funny thrill ride. It's one of the most wildly entertaining, rousing and crowd-pleasing action films of the season.
A riveting, unconventionally intelligent and engrossing murder mystery boasting solid performances and a delicate balance of intrigue, thrills, romance and comedy.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An overlong, strained and poorly-paced drama with that suffers from Omar Metwally's bland performance and excessive style over substance. It can't be saved by an otherwise terrific cast, beautiful scenery and exquisite production values.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Tedious, confusing, excessively poetic and an ultimately squandered opportunity to clearly and engagingly illuminate the life and work of 14 brilliant, important female artists.
A captivating, illuminating and delightfully amusing celebration of a long-lost and misunderstood art form.
A fascinating, heartwarming and delightful inspiration for your mind, body and soul.

Overstuffed and occasionally meandering while boasting a terrific ensemble cast and a radiant, brave performance by Gillian Anderson. It's an unflinchingly honest, provocative potpourri of the harsh realities of the art world.

Tackles an intriguing premise, but squanders its opportunity to be brave and powerful because of its lazy, pedestrian screenplay that fails to breath any life into its characters and to profoundly explore its provocative issues about faith.
Somewhat clever, heartfelt and much darker than its predecessors, but it's ultimately forgettable and not nearly as diverting as it could have been for kids and adults simultaneously.
An often contrived, melodramatic and pedestrian war drama slightly elevated by Ulrich Tukur's captivating performance, exquisite production values and a modicum of suspense.

A moderately engaging, but uneven hodgepodge of comedy, action, drama and romance that lacks surprises, imagination and palpable thrills. It's barely saved by lively characters and all-around solid performances.
Has breathtaking scenery, but it's a lazy, meandering and unimaginative adventure with a poorly developed, frustratingly naïve and dull protagonist.
As inane, sloppily edited, painfully awkward and unintentionally funny as an Uwe Boll film.
An exhilarating and thrilling adventure brimming with lush, breathtaking visuals, lively musical numbers and a captivating love triangle.
A slick and action-packed, but so brainless, thrill-less, unfunny and tedious that you'll yearn for any of the 80's and 90's classic action comedies.
An asinine, painfully unfunny, immature, and boring waste of celluloid. It's a sad reminder that we're still living in the Age of Stupid.
Genuinely engrossing, harrowing and unflinching. It's one of the most important, timely and provocative documentaries of the year.
An amusing, well-acted and intelligent slice of social commentary.
movie_title: Otona no miru ehon - Umarete wa mita keredo (I Was Born, But ) (Children of Tokyo) (1932)

movie_review_blurb: engaging, illuminating and occasionally funny, but awkwardly and distractingly blends Spector's songs and murder trial footage.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Breathtaking, captivating and inspirational. It's a non-preachy, vital wake-up call for all of mankind.
Briefly loses its footing during the first hour, but still manages to be an imaginative, witty, poignant and hilarious adventure that will captivate everyone. Bring on Toy Story 4!
Poorly-acted, bland, overlong and thrill-less. It insults your intelligence from start to finish.
A triumph of both story and animation that's thrilling, witty, hilarious, heartfelt and entertaining for kids and adults simultaneously.
Often lazy and somewhat tedious, but mindlessly exciting and thrilling on a purely visceral level thanks to Nimród Antal's deft directing skills.
A captivating, honest, unpretentious and intelligent portrait of an American family that's genuinely poignant, warm and funny. It brims with well-nuanced, brave and resonating performances.
An unfocused, pedestrian and somewhat convoluted thriller deficient in palpable thrills and clever surprises. Noomi Rapace's raw, sizzling performance remains a guilty pleasure
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A brain-dead blockbuster high on action sequences, CGI and silliness, but low on fun, thrills and imagination. Where's the magic when you really need it the most?
A picturesque travelogue and an enchanting ode to mankind's symbiotic relationship with nature.
A groundbreaking, intriguing, exhilarating and brilliant sci-fi thriller that's destined to become a timeless classic. Mark my words: It will be remembered for years to come.
Exquisitely-shot and deeply affecting with just the right balance of humor, sweetness and grittiness. Newcomers Kelly O'Neill and Shane Curry shine in raw, heartfelt and charismatic performances.
A candid, engaging and comprehensive documentary filled with revealing and fascinating interviews.
A boring, nauseating blockbuster filled with poor editing, painfully wooden acting, unrelenting dullness, and unimpressive special effects. It's so bad that it's gone past good and back to bad again.
Heartfelt and engagingly filmed, but not nearly as insightful as it could have been with sharper, more provocative questions asked.
An enlightening, provocative and captivating spiritual journey well worth taking.
A quietly enchanting, captivating, visually striking and narration-less mosaic of Sidney, Ohio.
An unconventional and wildly imaginative combination of humor, satire and faux documentary as a delightful and refreshing medium to enlighten the audience about Juche.
Vapid, overlong, painfully unfunny, preposterous and, worst of all, boring. It's so bad that it's gone past good and back to bad again.
An informative, well-edited and engaging documentary that needs a more thorough and provocative conclusion.
movie_title: Picasso and Braque Go to the Movies (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A well-acted, intermittently heartfelt drama that suddenly loses steam and becomes bland, unengaging and leaves you feeling ultimately underwhelmed.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Wildly imaginative, outrageously funny, daring, delightfully twisted and filled with eye-popping visual panache.
A tedious, choppily edited, uninvolving mess that can't be saved by its provocative premise and Rachel Weisz's radiant performance.
Mildly entertaining, stylishly edited, but neither synthesized nor provocative enough to be a truly enlightening experience
A creepy, slick and initially provocative sci-fi thriller that eventually loses steam once its surprises, cleverness and imagination wane midway.
Somewhat amusing, but often cringe-worthy, cheesy, silly and, worst of all, fails to engage kids and adults simultaneously.
Provocative, eye-opening and riveting, but not well-balanced or thorough enough to persuade simple-minded skeptics of alternative treatments.
Banal, asinine and frustratingly preposterous while lacking chemistry, laughs or even a modicum of cleverness.
A contrived, overlong, convoluted and emotionally hollow political thriller that's high on production values and style, but low on substance, palpable suspense and poignancy.
Intriguing, bittersweet, tender and refreshingly unpredictable with beautiful cinematography and a radiant performance by Alicja Bachleda.
Captivating, suspenseful, inspirational and profoundly illuminating.
A tediously dull, facile and lazy documentary that fails to engage viewers intellectually. It offers too many potatoes and not nearly enough meat.
A mindlessly entertaining blockbuster brimming with thrilling action sequences and delightfully zany characters that never take themselves too seriously.
Overstays its welcome, lacks surprises and feels intermittently captivating thanks to Jaden Smith's charming, heartfelt and star-making performance.
An eye-opening, provocative and heartfelt documentary that will inspire you to debate and discuss the issue of charter schools openly and intelligently.
Lacks adequate suspense and intrigue, occasionally drags, and leaves you feeling underwhelmed despite strong, well-nuanced performances and a richly atmospheric setting.
A gut-bustingly funny, endearing and unflinchingly honest documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually as well as emotionally.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, well-researched documentary that simultaneously informs and captivates the audience.

An inspirational drama that's somewhat unfocused and occasionally veers toward contrivance and oversimplification, but remains engaging thanks to Famiglietti's brave, warm and charismatic performance.
Marginally fascinating and well-edited, but has too much potatoes and not nearly enough meat for audiences hungry for insight about the second Golden Age of Animation.
Intriguing, well-structured and mildly engaging with strong performances, but its balance of comedy, melodrama and romance feels slightly uneven and contrived.
An unconventionally tender, heartfelt, well-acted and intriguing ghost story that offers both style and substance.
A leisurely paced, gently engrossing crime drama with an exceptionally witty and thought-provoking finale.

Refreshingly mature, funny and endearing with a terrific cast and razor sharp dialogue. Meryl Streep sizzles in a sexy, bold and honest performance. It's an intelligent American romcom with a very French sensibility.

A visually stylish rush of adrenaline with an amusing, engaging performance by Robert Downey, Jr., but there's too much nauseating action and not enough palpable excitement while the mystery itself lacks intrigue and suspense.
A delightful, visually splendid slice of brilliant madness that's occasionally uneven and too emotionally hollow to reach the heights of a true classic.
Engrossing, suspenseful and quietly haunting with exquisite cinematography and meticulous attention to detail.
A gritty, stylish crime thriller that's initially suspenseful and compelling, but eventually becomes pedestrian, unsurprising, preposterous and even somewhat tedious.
Poignant, well-shot and haunting, albeit somewhat repetitive at times.
An often wickedly funny and witty dark comedy that becomes somewhat uneven in tone and eventually loses its steam as well as its bite.
movie_title: A Film with Me in It (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A suspenseful, visually stylish and gory sci-fi thriller that's simultaneously entertaining and provocative.
Harmless, diverting and forgivably silly fun that will delight kids while keeping adults awake and, for the most part, amused.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Whimsical, mostly engaging and occasionally funny, but it's too uneven, pretentious, and lacks genuine poignancy as a coming of age story.
A fascinating, alarming and well-balanced documentary that sheds light on a very timely and provocative issue.
Despite its lack of piercing questions, In Search of Memory manages to be a captivating, illuminating and delightful documentary filled with surprising moments of humor and charm.
movie_title: In Search of Memory (Auf der Suche nach dem Gedächtnis) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Breezy, charming and harmless albeit very formulaic, contrived and forgettable while overstaying its welcome.
Funny, wise, tender and well-nuanced while boasting a radiant, genuinely charming performance by Arianne Martin.
An entertaining comedy loaded with action and laughs for all ages. It's forgivably silly, cartoonish and far from a classic, but nonetheless feels fast, funny, fresh and harmless.

Overstays its welcome and feels preposterous, sophomoric, pretentious and barely engaging thanks to the talents of Denzel Washington & Gary Oldman. It might make for a great midnight movie to laugh at given its abundance of absurdity & mindless violence.
A captivating, deeply moving, illuminating and well-balanced documentary for everyone, pet owner or not.
An emotionally devastating, well-shop and captivating coming-of-age drama boasting a brave and raw performance by the radiant Katie Jarvis.

Thoroughly engaging, inspirational, illuminating and genuinely uplifting. It's the rare kind of documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually.
Engrossing, riveting, amusing and filled with panache and a wickedly offbeat sense of humor. It's an incredible feat of filmmaking that must be seen to be believed.
movie_title: Flooding With Love for the Kid (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts an all-star ensemble cast, lively musical numbers, but it suffers from style over substance with an uneven balance of drama and romance that leaves you unmoved and underwhelmed.
Refreshingly unpredictable, imaginative, funny and provocative, but it eventually becomes a bit uneven, awkward and lacks emotional resonance.
A compelling, provocative and enlightening documentary that will open your eyes to the true horrors of our morally corrupt health industry.
An invigorating, lively and captivating crime drama boasting a terrific cast, sharp dialogue and just the right amount of dark comic relief.
Tedious, dull and anticlimactic despite decent performances and exquisite cinematography filled with bleak images. It's ultimately an underwhelming experience that lacks emotional resonance.
A thoroughly fun, magical, thrilling and captivating adventure filled with stunning animation, a lively soundtrack, a big heart and plenty of laughs for everyone both young and old.
A painfully unfunny attempt at comedy filled with lazy, juvenile, forced humor that's an insult to everyone's intelligence.
Thoroughly engaging, witty, charming and delightful. Christian McKay delivers a brilliant, utterly captivating and Oscar-worthy performance as Orson Welles.
Unfocused, emotionally hollow and just mildly engaging despite exquisite cinematography and radiant performances by Robin Wright Penn, Blake Lively and Maria Bello.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A poignant, heartfelt, enlightening and lyrical journey filled with beautiful, haunting images.
movie_title: Before Tomorrow (Le Jour avant le lendemain) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A provocative, elliptical and oddly fascinating work of experimental art.
movie_title: FILM IST. a girl & a gun (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, honest, quietly moving and funny with charismatic, lively performances and a witty screenplay.
An outrageously funny, irreverent comedy that will have you in stitches, as long as you're willing to check your brain at the door for 91 minutes.
A dull, unfocused and poorly directed documentary that lacks insight and fails to coherently and engagingly illuminate the subject of black metal.
Well-acted, funny and occasionally witty with terrific make-up design. However, it's often convoluted, awkwardly paced and too uneven as a whole.
Initially intriguing, but ultimately lazy, half-baked, unfocused and not nearly as provocative as it could have been.
A quietly engrossing, refreshingly unconventional love story balanced with just the right amount of gentle humor, warmth and subtle charm.

Despite a captivating-as-always performance by Morgan Freeman, [it] ends up rather dull and underwhelming while lacking enough sharp attention on the dynamics of Mandela's friendship with Francois Pienaar off of the rugby field.

Well-acted, visually stunning and initially intriguing, but it quickly falls apart into an uneven, convoluted and unfocused mess that's neither gripping nor emotionally stirring. Its fatal flaw is excessive style over substance.
An outrageous, offbeat comedy that's often preposterous and silly, but nonetheless quite funny and delightfully bizarre.
A visually stylish, mildly engaging crime drama that's often tedious, sophomoric, increasingly dull and lacking in suspense.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sporadically amusing, but it often drags and feels contrived and dull while suffering from an uneven balance of comedy, drama, romance and social criticism.
movie_title: Rocket Singh - Salesman of the Year (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A brilliant, visual extravaganza that's simultaneously thrilling, provocative and surprisingly moving. It's destined to become a sci-fi classic.
A refreshingly zany, clever, funny and truly bizarre comedy of errors that will delight audiences, young and old.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Inspirational, genuinely heartfelt and captivating. It's a profound, tender and uplifting journey toward enlightenment and compassion.

Devoid of thrills, excitement and cleverness, despite an abundance of slick action sequences and Angelina Jolie's sizzling physique---errr---performance. For more bang for your buck, go watch Inception instead.
Somewhat silly and cheesy, but nonetheless amusing, whimsical and delightfully goofy with inspirational, feel-great messages for everyone young and old to appreciate.
Has strong performances and exquisite cinematography, but feels too bland, maudlin and ultimately underwhelming.
A slick, stylish and finely crafted albeit unsurprising horror film that delivers the requisite chills and thrills.
Endearing and wise with a captivating and emotionally raw, brave and honest performance by Brian Geraghty. It's one of the most refreshing, heartfelt and unforgettable American films of the year.
A provocative, illuminating and intriguing documentary.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and sporadically amusing, but lacks thrills, heart and cleverness. It's ultimately too scary for little kids and too unimaginative, pedestrian and bland for grown-ups.
Offers no surprises, is far from a classic and has forgettable characters, but at least it's mildly engaging thanks to solid performances and Fuqua's stylish directing.
A contrived, lazy drama that's increasingly asinine, unrealistic, awkward and over-the-top.
Quietly moving, well-nuanced, lyrical and breathtaking to behold.
Finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually. A very appropriate companion piece to The Hurt Locker.
An underwhelming war film that's low on tension, surprises, cleverness and intrigue while high on nauseating camerawork and lazy oversimplifications.
A thoroughly compelling, well-edited and riveting documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually.
Mildly amusing and charming, but often bland, tedious and not nearly as funny as it could have been with a gutsier and more imaginative screenplay.
[It] isn't shocking or surprising, but often amusing, honest and filled with interesting kernels of confessions from a wide range of lively screenwriters.
Captivating, taut, absorbing and invigorating with exquisitely stylish cinematography and a mesmerizing, tour de force by Giovanna Mezzogiorno.
Slick and action-packed, but painfully insipid, needlessly gory, lackluster and, worst of all, fails to maintain its excitement, cleverness, imagination and thrills.
Overstays its welcome and ends up as one of the most unfunny, vapid and nauseatingly convoluted romcoms in recent memory. The lively supporting cast at least helps to keep you briefly awake.
An intriguing, elliptical and visually stylish journey into the unknown. It's a well-crafted, intelligent and unpredictable mystery that requires repeated viewings.
An intriguing, intelligent and suspenseful thriller boasting a radiant, captivating performance by the scene-stealing Noomi Rapace.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Sensationally entertaining...Demme captures [Neil] Young's pure, unadulterated passion and love for music in a way that no words can truly [describe].
An exciting, thrilling, soaring adventure with the rare combination of dazzling visual effects and a heartfelt story that's captivating for everyone both young and old.
A seductive and mostly intriguing erotic thriller that eventually loses steam and veers toward silliness while failing to trust the audience's intelligence. Amanda Seyfried sizzles.
A riveting, intelligent and engrossing murder-mystery boasting an unforgettably brave and captivating performance by Kim Hye-ja.
The animated short films are each lively and imaginative in their own unique ways...The most witty, clever and poignant live-action short [is] Miracle Fish.

A sweet, charming and warm romantic drama that suffers from being lazy, inorganic and seriously lacking in character development. The only scene-stealing, lively character is actually the city of New York itself.
An overlong, nauseating thriller lacking palpable suspense and clever twists which can't be saved by its exquisite production values and solid performances.
A somewhat meandering, but nonetheless engaging, refreshing and character-driven drama with just the right touch of offbeat comedy.
An initially intriguing policier that gradually loses suspense and cleverness as it bites off more than it can chew.
A captivating concert film that deftly captures Cohen's soulful performance that's filled with beautiful lyrics and pure, unadulterated passion, emotion and charisma.
movie_title: Leonard Cohen Live at the Isle of Wight 1970 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts solid performances and some wickedly funny dialogue, but it's often tedious, underwhelming and fails to pack any real punches.
Ssuspenseful, meticulously crafted, harrowing and thrilling. It's an incredible true story about courage and the power of the human spirit.
A captivating, insightful, revealing and surprisingly moving documentary.
Crowd-pleasing, heartfelt and inspirational. It's a wonderful, uplifting, and life-affirming movie.
A brutally honest, harrowing and provocative glimpse into the cycle of violence in the Middle East.
Bland, excessively corny, schmaltzy and contrived while lacking any requisite romantic chemistry. It cannot be saved by picturesque scenery and attractive leads alone.
A stylish, suspenseful, gritty and intriguing crime saga.
Brave, provocative and gently engrossing with well-nuanced performances.
A taut, intriguing and refreshingly well-crafted crime thriller brimming with many clever twists and turns.
A well-balanced, important and timely documentary that's provocative and eye-opening regardless of whether or not you agree with Finkelstein's controversial arguments.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Stale, unfunny, painfully dull, asinine and charmless. It's the antithesis of everything that a truly great romantic comedy ought to be.
Wisually stylish and initially suspenseful, but too unevenly paced while deficient in surprises, imagination and palpable thrills.
Captivating, inspirational and profoundly illuminating. It's a life-affirming celebration of compassion, hope, persistence and generosity of heart.
An enlightening, well-edited, haunting, thoroughly compelling and unflinchingly honest documentary that's essential viewing for every family, whether dysfunctional or not.
Marginally engaging and amusing, but often lazy, meandering, unenlightening, excessively facile and underwhelming.
Captivating, well-acted and heartfelt with inspirational, important messages about tolerance, compassion, endurance, hope, honesty and, above all, the power of love.

An endearing, suspenseful and well-edited documentary bursting with harsh truths about love, the vicissitudes of marriage and the innate struggles to find one's true happiness, identity and liberation.
Visually rich, provocative and engrossing with a quietly tender, radiant performance by the reliable-as-always Sylvie Testud.
Lacks sufficient focus, plausibility and an emotional core despite being provocative with a terrific ensemble cast and ...milie Dequenne's charming, radiant performance.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Often contrived, stilted and awkwardly preachy albeit occasionally suspenseful and filled with haunting visuals.
Outrageously funny, delightful and heartfelt. Steve Carell has never been funnier. You'll laugh 'til it hurts.
A complex, unpredictable and exhilarating crime thriller that's just as suspenseful and captivating as The Departed.
Deeply moving, powerful and inspiring. It radiates a rare glow of humor and warmth. J.K. Simmons gives by far the best performance of his career.
An engrossing, well-directed war drama that will keep you at edge of your seat.
Palinesque, bland and increasingly silly with oodles of unintentional humor instead of what every horror fan expects: palpable scares.
Big-hearted, inspirational and forgivably contrived with just the right amount of poignancy, excitement and comic relief to keep older and younger audiences captivated.
Tender, genuinely heartfelt, inspirational, refreshingly unpredictable and, above all, relatable.
A boring, frustratingly sluggish, highly elliptical experience with undeniably picturesque scenery and a sensitive performance by Bora Atlas. It would have worked much better as a short film.
A well-acted drama that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually. It will make you stand up and cheer.
Uninspired, bland, charmless and increasingly asinine. Only little kids might be fleetingly amused by the eye candy and sight gags.
Initially intense and suspenseful before tedium arrives. Adrien Brody delivers a captivating performance.
Atmospheric and initially intriguing, but often meandering and ultimately forgettable. It's deficient in enough scares, thrills and palpable tension to keep you thoroughly captivated.
The most certifiably insane, gut-bustingly funny horror comedy since Shaun of the Dead. It's best experienced late at night with a rowdy audience.
A contrived, silly mess with an irritating performance by Russell Brand. Greta Gerwig and Helen Mirren shine, though.
Well-acted and unflinching, but tedious, pretentious, overlong and tonally uneven.
A tender, captivating and well-acted drama abundant in humor and heart.
movie_title: The First Beautiful Thing (La prima cosa bella) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fleetingly rousing with impressive production values. It's often lackadaisical and contrived with a bland performance by the beautiful, but uncharismatic Mélanie Thierry.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhat pedestrian, but strong performances along with Robert Redford's impeccable skills as a director save the film from losing its dramatic momentum
An unchallenging, simplistic drama that's grounded by John Hawkes' genuinely tender and charismatic performance.
Sheer, mindless fun with oodles of over-the-top, stylized blood-'n-guts. Destined to become a cult classic that will have audiences laughing at it as well as with it.
An awkward, uneven amalgamation of drama and comedy with more cringe-inducing moments than laughter or poignancy, despite uniformly strong performances.
An overlong, mildy entertaining blockbuster that could have used a more charismatic lead as well as more palpable thrills and excitement.
Captivating, unflinchingly honest and poignant.
Tedious, lazy and thoroughly nauseating with no palpable thrills or excitement to be found. The asinine script and excessive use of shaky-cam will make your eyes and ears bleed simultaneously.
An often suspenseful, visually stylish and atmospheric whodunit despite a hackneyed romantic subplot and plenty of stilted dialogue to boot.
Quietly engrossing and fascinating with well-nuanced performances by Juliette Binoche and William Shimell.
An uneven, dull and painfully asinine action comedy that's neither thrilling, funny nor visually stylish enough to deliver pure entertainment. Go rent Kick-Ass instead.
Often engaging with just the right balance of poignancy and comedy, although it takes a while for it to gather dramatic momentum. Skarsgård delivers a convincingly heartfelt performance.
A witless albeit sexy romcom that's often contrived, sophomoric, overstuffed and low on palpable chemistry. It's far from a modern-day classic, but Natalie Portman sure does sizzle.
A chilling, intelligent and atmospheric thriller brimming with suspense, exquisite cinematography and a captivating performance by Jeon Do-yeon.
An exhilarating adventure that offers compelling characters, a wonderfully imaginative story and dazzling special effects. Newbies might feel slightly perplexed, though.
Thoroughly fascinating, heartfelt and unflinchingly candid.
Stylish, initially provocative, [but] suffers from increasing implausibility, oversimplifications, diminishing suspense and a bland, unengaging performance by Colin O'Donoghue.
Viscerally exhilarating and thrilling in its brilliantly-choreographed fight sequences, but less engaging during its contrived moments of drama.
movie_title: Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mildly compelling and amusing, but somewhat uneven and dull. The sexy Trieste Kelly Dunn invigorates the film in a radiant, charismatic performance.
Thrill-less, contrived albeit visually stunning adventure with laughably stilted dialogue and characters so devoid of life that you'll end up rooting for mother nature.
Mildly captivating albeit one-sided and over-simplified. It merely presents a reader's digest overview of climate change solutions [that's] more overwhelming than inspirational.
A somewhat meandering, yet provocative and lyrical documentation of a village's history, its evolution and the memories of its 14 villagers.
Offers three beautifully written films and two weaker ones that could have fleshed out with more imagination. God of Love deserves to win the Oscar.
Essentially a lazy porno with an dull plot, poor performances and tacked-on, underexplored sociopolitical messages.
Suffers from so much style over substance, lack of internal logic, contrived subplots and wooden performances that it makes Twilight look like Gone with the Wind.
Poignant, haunting and profound with thoroughly captivating performances. It's one of the most powerful and unforgettable films of the year.
A heartfelt and inspirational drama about the healing power of grace, reconciliation and forgiveness.
A captivating, heartfelt and unflinchingly honest documentary brimming with warmth and humor.
Amusing and thrilling albeit slightly overlong with dazzling visuals and clever nods to classic Westerns.
Mostly intriguing, suspenseful and clever until it loses steam during the underwhelming, facile, anticlimactic third act.
An intelligent, suspenseful and relentlessly terrifying crime thriller with one of the nastiest villains in the history of cinema.
Cringe-inducing, uneven, juvenile, overlong and painfully unfunny. It's a witless blend of crudeness, rudeness and lewdness which sets a new low for American comedy.
A powerful, unflinchingly honest and intense experience that captivates you on a visceral level.
Thrilling and exhilarating. Prepare to be at the edge of your seat from start to finish.
Bland...with too many unanswered questions and missed opportunities.
A suspenseful, unflinchingly albeit pedestrian and emotionally uninvolving thriller that's saved by Rachel Weisz's bravura performance.
Epic with production values and a terrific ensemble cast, but often bland and emotionally hollow.
movie_title: The Beginning of a Great Revival (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wickedly funny and irreverent. The best dark comedy since In Bruges. It will leave you in stitches.
Often boring, tedious and only fleetingly insightful.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A mildly engaging, slight and somewhat breezy slice-of-life drama that's instantly forgettable.
Stylishly directed and palpably frightening because it leaves more to your imagination than most horror films do.
A well-acted, intelligent drama filled with tenderness, warmth and humor. Its characters will stay ingrained in your mind long after the end credits roll.
A lazy, witless sex comedy that's low on both sex and comedy.
A very entertaining, well-acted and palpably taut piece of propaganda that leaves too little room for interpretation.
A grossly unfunny, asinine example of the tragic decline of American comedy. It will compel you to ask: "Should I vomit inside the theater, outside, or both?"
A mildly funny dark comedy with iconic British wit and tongue-in-cheek humor.

Atmospheric, refreshingly intelligent and suspenseful with a well-nuanced performance by Ryan Gosling. It's one of the most invigorating thrillers of the year because it offers both style and substance.
The most powerful, honest and engrossing romantic drama since  Before Sunrise .
The best unintentional comedy of the year.
Funny, heartfelt, well-acted and refreshingly honest. It's one of the best movies of the year.

Quite cheesy, yet exhilarating and mindlessly entertaining. It's a fun, crowd-pleasing popcorn movie that will leave you hungry for a sequel. Child star Dakota Goyo has a very bright future ahead of him.
Suspenseful, disturbing and creepy. Pollyanna McIntosh gives a raw, brave performance.
A palpably terrifying experience that will haunt you for days. It should be watched on the big screen in a crowded theater. Bring on number 4!
An often amusing, harmless and sporadically funny "documentary."
A very funny, clever and crowd-pleasing comedy with a terrific ensemble cast. It deserves to become an instant classic.
Serves as a vital wake-up call and manages to be simultaneously entertaining, provocative and enraging--just as all harsh truths, sans euphemisms, should be presented.
Amusing, initially smart and heartfelt with plenty of charm thanks to its terrific ensemble cast, but it eventually becomes contrived, uneven and sophomoric.
Poignant and filled moments of tenderness, humor and warmth.
A daring, brilliant, profound and visionary modern masterpiece. It will go down as a classic.

Not nearly as consistently exhilarating as the first installment, but, with Rob Marshall at the helm, it's less convolute and more thrilling than the last two. Stick around after the end credits for a stinger.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An occasionally funny comedy that's far from poignant or true-to-life, but it's nonetheless harmless, breezy and amusing more often than not.
Marginally engrossing and witty, yet somewhat contrived and lacking in depth.
A mesmerizing experience filled with breathtaking sights and sounds. It's much like life itself: visceral, enigmatic, spiritual, profound and simply complex.
Refreshingly funny, poignant and wonderfully perceptive with razor-sharp wit. It's the kind of rare coming-of-age film that's well-acted and abundant in both style and substance.
An often captivating documentary that will tug at your heartstrings, especially if you're an animal lover

A hackneyed, overlong soap opera with decent performances, a seemingly interesting premise and beautiful scenery, but neither of those can compensate for its contrived, unmoving and often pedestrian screenplay.

An underwhelming sci-fi adventure with nifty special effects and strong performances by its child actors, but it's weakened by a bland, uneven screenplay that lacks palpable thrills, suspense and internal logic.
Ye Liu gives a warm and tender performance, and Qi Shu sizzles, but the film [eventually] becomes too melodramatic and occasionally drags.
movie_title: A Beautiful Life (Bu Zai Rang Ni Gu Dan) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Asinine, nauseating and often dull with no thrills or excitement to be found. It'll make your eyes and ears bleed simultaneously.
A politically incorrect farce that's increasingly preposterous and inane yet nonetheless hilarious, zany and bold. Amy Sedaris has never been funnier.
A refreshingly mature, perceptive and engrossing coming-of-age drama that boasts a well-nuanced, tender performance by newcomer Jacob Wysocki.
Inspiring and stylishly directed albeit an awkward, uneven blend of drama, musical and fantasy elements.
An excruciatingly contrived, bland and asinine romantic comedy that lacks both romance and comedy. You'd be more entertained watching paint dry.
A simultaneously fascinating, captivating, thorough and insightful documentary.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another captivating, heartfelt, provocative and stylishly edited documentary from the brilliant James Marsh.
Despite its somewhat contrived turn of events, Girlfriend manages to be genuinely endearing with beautiful cinematography and a heartfelt, raw performance by newcomer Evan Sneider
A provocative, captivating and surprisingly funny documentary. Joyce McKinney deserves to be nominated for Best Actress of the Year.
Profoundly moving, unflinching, inspirational and eye-opening. It boasts a brave, genuinely heartfelt performance by newcomer Khomotso Manyaka.
Heartfelt and stylishly edited with picturesque scenery, but it's often redundant, underwhelming and neither suspenseful nor insightful enough to be truly inspirational or captivating.
A thrilling, exciting and enormously entertaining blockbuster that delivers plenty of exhilarating action, solid performances and the right amount of comic relief.
Well-edited and captivating with easily digestible information albeit sans surprising revelations.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An unpretentious, genuinely engrossing and funny modern romance brimming with well-nuanced performances, a terrific musical score, and meticulous attention to the details of everyday life.
A well-acted albeit dull prison drama that's often tedious before it kicks into thriller mode too late in game.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tedious, asinine, jejune and so painfully unfunny that it will make your eyes and ears bleed.
Whip-smart, compelling, well-acted, wickedly funny, bold and visually stylish without a trace of pretentiousness.
Suspenseful, surprising, somewhat terrifying and clever despite its rushed, lazy conclusion.
A wholesome, genuinely heartfelt, sweet and uplifting story that everyone, young and old, can easily fall in love with.
Often funny, refreshingly original, imaginative and unpredictable, although it could use more satirical bite.
Outrageous, disturbing and wickedly funny. It's a stylish, bizarre and refreshingly subversive amalgamation of horror, romance and comedy.
Unconventionally slow-paced, low on palpable thrills and often dull despite its brilliant, exquisite cinematography. It ultimately suffers from excessive style over substance.
A witty, honest and genuinely poignant tale filled with wisdom and humor. It's unlike any dog movie you've ever seen before.
A taut, captivating, well-acted and thrilling war film.
One of the most outrageously entertaining, tongue-in-cheek guilty pleasures since Kill Bill---as long as you're willing to check your brain at the door from start to finish.
A provocative and absorbing drama filled with haunting, powerful imagery.
An uneven, painfully contrived and uninspired romantic comedy that's low on laughs and chemistry while high on awkward dirty talk and unnecessary foul language.
Often stilted and uninvolving amalgamation of drama, tragedy, romance and awkward musical numbers. Jan O'Dell steals the show with her genuinely heartfelt performance.
A quietly intense, engrossing and intelligent drama brimming with haunting imagery and poignant lyricism.
An invigorating, campy and high-spirited journey well worth taking. It's one of the most delightful, heartfelt and crowd-pleasing musical comedies in years.
A refreshing, pleasantly diverting romantic comedy that offers plenty of laughs, escapism and charm.
[Katie Aselton] grounds each scene in a sense of realism while tackling, sans preachiness, the universal issues of fidelity, trust, friendship and love with sensitivity.
A well-acted, suspenseful, refreshingly intelligent and character-driven crime thriller with just the right balance of action, drama and comic relief.
Such an unconventionally smart, funny and delightful teen comedy that it's like a breath of fresh air. It's this year's Mean Girls.
[It] squanders an intriguing premise with an uneven, lazy and painfully juvenile screenplay that's low on laughs and imagination.
A somewhat amusing, funny and heartfelt blend of reality and fiction with no real surprises to offer and a social message that's far from profound.
A whimsical, uplifting, funny and unexpectedly engrossing journey with just the right balance of comedy and drama.
An enchanting, provocative, bighearted story that will inspire you to cherish the priceless values of family, faith, love and compassion.
A grand-slam comic drama that's heartwarming, funny, inspirational and, above all, triumphant.
Heartfelt and occasionally funny albeit unsurprising and somewhat contrived. Newcomer Thomas Henderson steals the show in the best performance by a child actor in recent memory.
Provocative, unflinchingly honest, harrowing and unforgettable. It's among the most powerful and important documentaries of the year.
A hackneyed, disjointed, painfully corny and contrived drama that can't be saved by breathtaking scenery or Zac Efron's charming performance. It's best suited as a Lifetime TV movie-of-the-week.
A lazy, painfully dull, unfunny and nauseatingly silly action comedy that should have gone direct-to-DVD.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unfocused, dry and boring. It's a squandered opportunity to extensively and compellingly tackle provocative political, social and moral issues plaguing America.
Poorly-directed and often drags while lacking palpable tension. Robert Duvall and Sissy Spacek's well-nuanced performances can't save it from sinking into a mostly forgettable, stale drama.

Absorbing, wise, true-to-life and universally relatable with just the right balance of sweetness, tenderness and humor. Trieste Kelly Dunn shines in a charismatic, warm and genuinely heartfelt performance.
Refreshingly original, spirited and provocative. Get ready for a surprisingly enlightening and amusing experience.
Often silly, but very, very funny and well-cast. Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg have terrific chemistry and impeccable comic timing. It's one of the best buddy flicks since Rush Hour.
Unabashedly corny, contrived and comes alive with irresistibly captivating, eye-popping energy during the vibrant dance numbers.

Far from a classic and won't tug at your heartstrings, but it manages to be captivating from top to bottom with a refreshingly sharp and funny screenplay, a great ensemble cast and a lively soundtrack.
An unpredictable, taut and well-acted thriller with just the right balance of intrigue, palpable suspense and comic relief.
A gentle, bittersweet love story boasting a picturesque, enchanting travelogue of Cairo and a radiant, well-nuanced and engrossing performance by the genuinely beautiful Patricia Clarkson.
A richly human, heartfelt, character-driven and atmospheric war drama.

Often funny, delightfully tongue-in-cheek, character-driven and wildly imaginative. It's a refreshingly witty, diverting adventure that blends fantasy and realism while never taking itself too seriously.
Overlong, repetitive, too simplistic, and bland despite oodles of breathtaking scenery. It's like a healthy dish that looks aesthetically pleasing, but lacks flavor and needs a more talented chef.
A down and dirty action adventure, and the best escapist entertainment around. Check your brain at the door for non-stop rowdy, riotous and raucous fun.
A captivating, well-acted, intense and suspenseful thriller that suffers from excessive flashbacks and a contrived romantic subplot.
Provocative, well-balanced, unflinchingly honest and profoundly moving with just the right amount of comic relief and non-preachy, inspirational messages.

Delightfully entertaining, heartfelt and inspirational. It will keep you at the edge of your seat while making you cheer, laugh and feel genuinely awestruck by the sheer beauty of each piano performance.
An often fascinating, sporadically funny glimpse into the complex art of improv.
movie_title: Trust Us, This Is All Made Up (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhat silly, yet genuinely sweet, often amusing and pleasantly diverting for everyone young and old. Please be sure to stick around after the end credits for a stinger.
A thrilling adventure full of imagination and humor. It's the best animated film of the season. You don't have to be a kid to enjoy it.
Profoundly moving, intelligent and unflinching. It boasts a brave, emotionally devastating performance by Jeon Do-yeon.
A relentlessly terrifying, pulse-pounding and intelligent thriller. Ryan Reynolds gives his best performance yet. It's the most intense movie-going experience in years.
Well-edited, heartfelt and captivating, but not thorough or well-balanced enough to be truly enlightening.
An indolent and painfully unfunny attempt at comedy with uninspired, forced humor and annoying characters that have zero chemistry.
A smart, funny, genuinely heartfelt and uplifting coming-of-age story.
Slightly uneven and often contrived, but nonetheless entertaining, funny and bold. Mindy Cohn shines in a heartfelt performance filled with panache.
A taut, action-packed, mindless thriller that delivers a pure rush of adrenaline.
A perceptive, funny and poignant slice-of-life brimming with sharp dialogue and interesting, believable characters worth getting to know.
Spellbinding! An enlightening and profoundly moving experience!
The kind of rare documentary that simultaneously informs and delights even those who don't care much about history or politics.
movie_title: Disco and Atomic War (Disko ja tuumasoda) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhat unevenly paced and lacks exposition, but there's no denying its stylish, exquisite production values. Avid Harry Potter fans will be captivated, thrilled and left drooling for Part 2.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Uplifting, delightful and inspirational. Sally Hawkins delivers a radiant, genuinely heartfelt performance.
Hilarious, refreshingly smart, thrilling and heartfelt. It will delightfully entertain everyone, young or old, good or evil.

Occasionally loses its focus and drags, but it nonetheless remains compelling, provocative and, for the most part, emotionally resonating thanks to raw performances and a delicately woven, character-driven screenplay.
A provocative and funny satire that's somewhat uneven, awkward and contrived. Tanna Frederick once again proves to be a sexy, charismatic and immensely talented actress.
A poorly-paced, bland and underwhelming drama that can't be saved by its authentic production values nor by Washington and Mackie's strong performances.
An intriguing blend of mystery, suspense, drama and supernatural thrills that slightly loses steam as its trust in the audience's intelligence wanes.

Imaginative, visually stylish and refreshingly character-driven albeit somewhat contrived. It could have been much more brilliant and compelling had it taken more risks by increasing its satirical bite.
A rousing, captivating and heartfelt sports drama filled with terrific performances. It's a knockout!

A poignant, true-to-life portrait of an emotionally scarred, lonely and depressed soul struggling to grow up in this often cold, alienating world. Stella Schnabel delivers a raw, captivating performance.
Gritty and action-packed, but often contrived and monotonous while lacking enough of a heart and brain to be a truly suspenseful and engrossing Russian gangster film.
A dull, disgusting and underwhelming semi-satire that's bold in its concepts, but neither scary, funny nor clever in its execution.
A vapid and brainless blockbuster that's exhilarating on a purely aesthetic level, but suffers from laughably stilted dialogue and excessive style over substance.
A captivating, breathtaking and intricately layered amalgamation of heartfelt drama, romance and magical realism. It's one of the most powerful love stories since Brokeback Mountain.
Captivating, inspirational and profoundly eye-opening. It's a testament to the true healing power of art.
A character-driven drama that too often and bores you with its sluggish pace and poor editing. James Gandolfini and Melissa Leo anchor the film in raw, well-nuanced performances.
Vapid, convoluted, tedious and too episodic despite Jessica Chastain's charismatic performance as the seductive, wounded, insecure and lonely Jolene.
Riveting, powerful and genuinely heartfelt. Mira Sorvino deserves an Oscar for her raw, brave and captivating performance.
Lackluster, pedestrian, emotionally hollow and underwhelming despite exquisite cinematography and a timely, initially intriguing premise.
A series of 9 short films that mostly impress with stylish animation, clever concepts, poignancy and, at times, a sense of humor. The best film among the bunch is FLATLIFE.
An asinine, lazy, juvenile and painfully unfunny attempt at comedy.
A dazzling, exhilarating, refreshingly character-driven and thoroughly captivating experience that must be seen on the big screen. It's unlike any martial arts film you've seen before.
A focused and mostly compelling drama with interesting characters and very natural, raw performances, but its lazy, rushed third act sinks it into mediocrity and blandness.
Often implausible and convoluted with stilted dialogue and an irritatingly over-the-top performance by Frank Whaley.
A quietly absorbing, refreshingly character-driven drama brimming with well-nuanced performances and enchanting scenery of Mumbai.
A bland, overlong, unfunny and forgettable romantic comedy that appeals to the lowest common denominator.
Schmaltzy, uneven and contrived [despite] thrilling horse-racing scenes and John Malkovich's hilarious performance as an eccentric trainer who walked right out of a Christopher Guest movie.
An imaginative, provocative and refreshingly unconventional, yet somewhat uneven amalgamation of sci-fi, drama, romance, tragedy and social commentary.
A suspenseful, captivating and provocative thriller that's epic in scope and boasts a powerful, star-making performance by Edgar Ramírez.
Well-acted, quietly moving and mildly intriguing, but not nearly as powerful as it could have been with a braver script that took more risks.
A strange, mildly provocative and imaginative "documentary" that eventually loses a little steam toward the end.
Unapologetically sick, perverted, deranged and profoundly inane. You'll have to see it to believe it.
A poetic, tender and unflinchingly real love story. Its powerful visuals, music and raw, captivating performances will leave you feeling deeply moved.
A quietly engrossing, funny and thought-provoking tragicomedy boasting lively characters and a well-nuanced performance by Fernando Luján.
Well-shot, but often lazy, tedious and, above all, boring. It's one of the most unenlightening and underwhelming documentaries of the year.
A pedestrian thriller that suffers from implausibility, an overbearing musical score and excessive style over substance.
A lackadaisical albeit stylishly directed thriller deficient in suspense, imagination and genuine poignancy.
A poignant, honest and voyeuristic quest filled with insight and humor.
A viscerally disturbing visual feast that wallows to the point of tedium in its ugly world of relentless sex, violence and drugs while leaving you feeling cold and filthy.
Sensationally entertaining, darkly comedic, witty and refreshingly bizarre. A guilty pleasure. Nicolas Cage is in top form.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An illuminating, compelling and well-focused documentary. Just like Milton Glaser's artworks, it concurrently informs and delights.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An often amusing, harmless adventure with enough inoffensive humor and impressive CGI animation to make up for its lack of exhilarating moments and refreshing surprises.

A profoundly engrossing and inspirational film that candidly explores Arthur Blessitt's passionate heart, mind and soul, but feels somewhat incomplete without enough insight into his life beyond his courageous journeys around the world.
movie_title: The Cross(The Cross: The Arthur Blessitt Story) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its rich, picturesque scenery and a few briefly amusing and tender moments, Tulpan feels uneven, meandering, unimaginative and somewhat bland both as a drama and as a comedy.
Has sporadically provocative and amusing moments, but remains poorly synthesized, somewhat unfocused and leaves you feeling underwhelmed and hungry for more enlightenment about yoga and spirituality.
A refreshingly honest, intelligent and captivating drama brimming with warmth, tenderness and razor-sharp humor.
Despite its impressive production design and lively cinematography, Paris 36 feels mostly bland, uneven and contrived with only a few fleeting moments of palpable charm, poignancy and vivacity.

A sweet, funny and mature drama. It has more tenderness and much less crassness than what its lousy, deceptive trailer leads you to believe. Kristen Steward shines in a raw and tender performance bursting with charisma.

Has plenty of visual eye candy with its slick cars and action-packed sequences, but it's ultimately low on surprises, imagination and palpable thrills, even if you're willing to suspend your disbelief and to check your brain at the door for 107 minutes.
An often engaging drama that tackles provocative issues, but, without a sensitive and intelligent screenplay, it ultimately fails to be truly moving, profound or memorable.
Occasionally drags, but feels refreshingly down-to-earth and has enough gentle humor, striking visuals and thought-provoking use of symbolism to be mostly compelling and amusing.
Initially compelling, but spins into a hodgepodge of contrived scenes, uneven drama and poorly developed, yet provocative issues that simmer for too long without actually coming to a boil.
Captivating, provocative and more sensationally thrilling than your average documentary.
A rousing film packed with solid performances and relentless suspense that brilliantly reinvigorates the genre of prison escape thrillers.

Has a few moments of offbeat humor and boasts a charming, tender performance, as usual, by Zooey Deschanel, but it often falls flat as a convoluted comedy, drama, mystery and romance. It has too many poorly developed storylines that simmer together for 98

Has a terrific ensemble cast with strong performances and occasional moments of razor-sharp wit and tenderness, but it eventually falls apart with a mostly contrived, unfocused plot that fails to be emotionally engrossing, powerful or haunting.
Mindless, silly and outrageously funny with hilarious, lively comedic performances and plenty of bold, inane and mean-spirited humor.

Falls flat as a contrived drama and dull, vapid comedy. Only easily pleased fans of Miley Cyrus will find it to be mildly amusing and harmless, but everyone else will often be painfully bored and wish that it were over sooner.

Those previously unfamiliar with Eddie Adams will be mostly fascinated and somewhat intrigued, but, for everyone else, An Unlikely Weapon serves merely as a pedantic, Reader's Digest version of Adams' career rather than as truly revealing and illuminating
A captivating, honest and thoroughly engrossing documentary with plenty of wisdom, panache and stunning visuals.
An honest, captivating, quietly poignant and illuminating documentary.
A delightful, crowd-pleasing comedy radiating with a charismatic performance by Zac Efron. It's pure, undiluted fun.

If you're willing to check your brain at the door and to suspend a lot of your disbelief, Alien Trespass manages to be a delightfully zany and campy satire best experienced at midnight with a group of friends.
Well-directed with exquisite visuals, but suffers from an often dull, convoluted and confusing plot as well as too much style over substance.
A moderately compelling and humorous documentary that leaves you wanting more revealing insight into the life and career of Cindy Sherman.

Has exquisite cinematography and occasional moments of tenderness, but its characters never truly come to life and its uneven screenplay doesn't fully explore their human struggles convincingly and sensitively enough to be make it an emotionally resonatin
Mostly compelling, warm and lively, but ultimately deficient in truly profound revelations or insights.
A pretentious, tedious, jarring and grueling test of a viewer's patience.
movie_title: Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A slightly prosaic and tedious, but mostly chilly and intense ride.
Feels somewhat disjointed, meandering, seemingly random and chaotic, but filled with fleeting moments of coherence, wonder and awe, much like life itself.

Those previously unfamiliar with the work of Valentino will find it to be sporadically interesting. Everyone else, especially fashion aficionados, will find it to be superficial, unprovocative and bland.
Has a terrific cast, stylish cinematography and some intrigue, but the suspense and sizzle wane as the intricate plot gradually thickens.
A refreshingly delightful and intelligent comedy filled with warmth, charisma and wit.
Heartbreaking, poignant, haunting and captivating from start to finish.
Boasts a radiant comedic performance by John Malkovich and a breezy, sporadically hilarious plot that increasingly becomes a lazy, contrived and uneven satire with not enough bite.
Despite stylish editing, lively performances and some effervescent dialogue, Skills Like This eventually becomes insipid, tedious, inane and a bit lackluster.
Convoluted, contrived and bland while failing to be truly endearing, insightful or believable in terms of drama and romance.

Occasionally compelling and provocative, but mostly underwhelming and lacking intrigue. At least it's a much more truthful depiction of America post-9/11 than the propaganda film Proud American, produced by American Airlines and Coca-Cola.
Much like its titular character, the film itself has some serious growing up to do and needs a strong dose of warmth and charisma.
Has interesting characters and a terrific cast, but feels somewhat contrived, bland and lacking an authentic emotional resonance.

Even if you manage to suspend your disbelief and to check your brain at the door, Super Capers still feels lazy, dull, painfully juvenile and void of any real thrills, laughs or even unintentionally funny moments.
A heartbreaking, profoundly illuminating and vital documentary. It will open your eyes, make you feel outraged and inspire you to demand immediate reform.

Despite spectacular visuals and sporadic thrills, Monsters vs. Aliens lacks the consistent fun, inventiveness, wit and big-heartedness found in superior, unforgettable CGI action-adventures such as The Incredibles.
Has a somewhat chilling atmosphere and stylishly eerie effects, but gives away too much information too fast and lacks the palpable tension and scares required to make it a truly haunting experience.
A lively and moderately engaging documentary, but its lack of thorough explorations leave you feeling slightly empty, underwhelmed and yearning for more insights.
A profoundly moving, raw, tender and gently uplifting drama that celebrates the importance of unconditional human compassion.
A delightfully sweet romantic comedy of manners filled with genuine charm, warmth and intelligent humor. It also makes for a very pleasant and satisfying date movie.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: State of Play isn't as intelligently woven or rewatchable as last year's superb murder mystery, Tell No One, but at least it has solid performances and enough surprises, thrills and tension to keep you at the edge of your seat.
An often captivating and engrossing drama with a sensitive, intelligent and tender screenplay.
A genuinely absorbing, compelling and wise drama with a well-nuanced, radiant and moving performance by Hiam Abbass, the heart and soul of the film.

Has solid performances that make it moderately compelling, but its weak screenplay merely simmers the provocative, initially intriguing issues of racial prejudice, police corruption and unjust laws without bringing them to a palpable boil.
An intelligent, well-nuanced and provocative drama that maintains its gradual suspense and intrigue throughout.
Has sporadically intriguing moments and stylish editing, but its lack of insight, elaborations and synthesis makes it seem deficient in both form and function as a documentary.
A brave, provocative and thoroughly compelling exposé that you'll be talking about for weeks.
A compelling, inspirational, provocative and thoroughly engrossing documentary.
feels lazy, bland and ultimately fails to pack a real punch emotionally, dramatically and comedically.

Boasts an electrifying, brave performance by Tilda Swinton and has a thrilling initial half, but eventually becomes tedious and convoluted while lacking plausibility and insight into the titular character.
A well-edited documentary that's equally informative and entertaining.
An often entertaining and intense blockbuster that's visually stunning, but suffers from a dumbed-down script that doesn't ultimately trust in the audience's own intelligence.
A brilliant, refreshingly original comedy that's delightfully zany and inventive.
Mildly engaging and absurdly funny, but that barely compensates for its lack of insight and profound revelations about Pastor Richard Gazowsky.

An entrancing and fascinating experience filled with equally imaginative, wondrous and bizarre sights and sounds. Much like the even more experimental film, The Flicker, it definitely deserves to be studied and thoroughly discussed in film school.

Has exquisite cinematography and an initially intriguing plot, but that doesn't compensate for its bland and meandering screenplay that lacks palpable dramatic tension and fails to bring any of its characters to life.
A cheesy B-movie that's initially refreshing, funny and a guilty pleasure, but eventually sinks into tedium while its comic energy and imagination concurrently diminish.
Mostly compelling and occasionally sweet and funny thanks to its terrific cast, but it combines comedy, drama and romance awkwardly and unevenly while leaving you feeling somewhat underwhelmed.
Suspenseful and captivating...[It] finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually as well as emotionally, without a dull moment from start to finish.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from style over substance. Its impressive CGI effects and editing make it look and sound great while providing some fleeting, visceral thrills and adrenaline-pumping excitement, but in terms of imagination and surprises, it falls flat.
An exhilarating, imaginative sequel filled with humor, excitement, wit and a lively cast. It's genuinely delightful and fun for everyone young and old.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even though the laughs eventually fizzle out toward the end, Easy Virtue nonetheless manages to be unadulterated fun...It's a sparkling, delightfully witty and frothy British comedy with a lively ensemble cast.
A visually stylish, sexy and provocative film that's emotionally cold, yet oddly intriguing.
A lively, engrossing, fascinating and well-edited documentary. It finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually as well as emotionally.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A taut, character-driven and intelligently crafted thriller with a strong and radiant performance by Nina Hoss.
Falls flat as both a dark comedy and action film. It's often lazy, dim-witted and tedious while low on laughs, verve and imagination.
Exciting, captivating and thrilling with eye-popping special effects. It's an exhilarating rush of adrenaline that will please Star Trek fans old and new.
Lyrical and quietly moving with lush cinematography and a sensitive, intelligent screenplay.
Has stylish visuals and a provocative, imaginative screenplay, but occasionally drags and feels convoluted with too many irritatingly awkward moments that lack an emotional core.

Entertaining for kids while slightly corny and silly for adults, but it's often harmless, bighearted and filled with inspirational messages about friendship, hope and the importance of family which everyone, young and old, can appreciate.
Occasionally drags, but it nonetheless manages to be a quietly engrossing, well-nuanced and sensitive drama filled with exquisite cinematography.
Has lots of stunning visuals and wonders of nature to behold, but ultimately lacks insight and never really achieves the exhilarating heights and palpable poignancy of March of the Penguins.

A captivating, inspirational and extraordinary story about the power of friendship and music. Jamie Foxx commands the screen in a brilliant, raw and profoundly moving performance. It's the first great film of 2009.
Filled with warmth, humor, tenderness and insight. It ultimately finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually as well as emotionally.

Has stylish editing and moderately exciting action sequences, but that doesn't come close to compensating for a contrived, bland screenplay that ultimately lacks palpable thrills and fails to pack any real punches when it comes to drama and romance.

boasts a bravura performance by Toni Servillo, stylish cinematography and a provocative premise, but it often feels convoluted and leaves you emotionally detached from the events onscreen. It's often compelling as a political thriller, but lacks insight a

A Touch of Spice has a few imaginative and amusing scenes as well as all the right ingredients of a romantic dramedy, but those ingredients merely simmer without coming to a boil. It often feels contrived and convoluted while its variety of ingredi
Tyson simply doesn't provoke you enough intellectually. It feels mildly compelling, occasionally moving and revealing, but it ultimately suffers from too much style over substance.

It's filled with lively, soulful musical performances that keeps you mostly compelled, but it eventually becomes somewhat dull and lacks enough profound insights, which ultimately leaves you feeling underwhelmed.

Despite a terrific ensemble cast, The Informers suffers from an uneven, chaotic screenplay with forgettable, poorly developed characters while none of the actors or actresses get a chance to shine. It never really gels into a sharp, compelling or e
An intriguing, focused and often captivating documentary filled with stunningly beautiful cinematography of the Antarctic landscape.
Intelligent, compelling and elegant with as many surprises and ambiguities as a great suspense thriller.
An action-packed ride filled with nonstop thrills and spectacular visual effects that deserves to be experienced on the big screen with a large crowd.

Even if you're willing to check your brain at the door and suspend your disbelief for 100 minutes, Ghosts of Girlfriends Past has just a few fleeting moments of hilarity, but ultimately falls flat as comedy, romance and drama...

Feels tedious, bland and pretentious. It's the kind of film that's more appropriate to be studied shot-by-shot in film school for its expert camera techniques and other production values instead of experiencing it with a movie theater audience.
Stylish cinematography along with decent performances don't compensate for an often tedious plot that lacks any real tension, imagination or palpable poignancy.
Has a somewhat witty and absurdly funny first half, but, at midpoint, it loses its dry humor and abruptly turns darker and feels too rushed, dull and contrived.
A surprisingly tender, sensitive and intelligent drama with well-nuanced performances. It's a solid directorial debut from Michael Keaton.
An absorbing, inspirational and often heartwarming drama with radiant, captivating performances by Marcia Gay Harden and her real-life daughter, Eulala Scheel.
Mostly entertaining, lively and occasionally riveting and moving, but its lack of insight and provocative revelations ultimately leave you feeling underwhelmed and unenlightened.
[An] unpretentious, engrossing, well-nuanced and tender drama brimming with a raw and powerfully moving performance by Sayuri Yoshinaga.

Has a lively cast, emotionally raw performances, plenty of charisma and a little quirkiness which just barely compensates for its awkward blend of dark comedy and drama as well as its somewhat contrived plot.

Has a charismatic performance by Steve Coogan, but that's not nearly enough to save it from drowning from its bland, awkward and lazy screenplay that fails to generate any real laughs or palpable dramatic tension.
Superb cinematography and fleeting moments of poignancy bogged down by a tedious, unfocused plot that occasionally drags and feels overstuffed with too many poorly developed characters.
It's a non-stop laugh riot that's destined to become a comedy classic.
Even Will Ferrell can't save the repetitive, inane and uninspired humor from often falling flat.
A fascinating, warm and delightfully charming documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually.

Boasts a raw and convincing performance by Yolande Moreau along with exquisite cinematography, but it often drags and suffers from lack of insight into the life and mind of Séraphine which keeps it from being an emotionally resonating experience.

Mildly engaging with an initially intriguing premise and brief moments of wittiness, but ultimately falls flat as a drama. Its bland protagonist, along with a lazy, unimaginative screenplay, leaves you feeling unmoved and underwhelmed.
Compelling and provocative with powerful images and quietly moving interviews that shed light on impact of social, economical and political changes on factory workers in China.

Boasts a raw, brave performance by Maria Bello and a stylish cinematography, but suffers from too much style over substance. Its dull, stilted screenplay has poorly developed characters and lacks any real suspense.
An illuminating, provocative and brave documentary that serves as a vital wake-up call for the sake of truth, democracy, good health and, above all, the evolution of mankind.
Visually arresting and intelligently crafted for the most part, but its slightly uneven tone diminishes its overall power to captivate and engross you thoroughly.

Sweet, tender and funny, despite some corny and contrived moments. As long as you're willing to suspend your disbelief and to lighten up for 107 minutes, you'll find it to be a delightful, genuinely heartwarming comedy for the whole family.
An illuminating, vital and provocative documentary that will open your eyes to the harsh truths about the food industry and will inspire you to change your diet to organic, unprocessed food.
A sporadically funny comedy that often shocks and disgusts, but falls flat with tedious and lazy humor.
A viscerally intense, gripping and character-driven thriller filled with pulse-pounding action, strong performances and stylish, gritty cinematography.
Silly, highly contrived and far from a classic, but it's ultimately a harmless comedic adventure with a terrific cast and plenty of mindless fun that should please its target audience: teenagers.
Initially refreshing, witty and awkwardly funny, but it morphs into a shallow, tedious, lazy and ultimately forgettable comedy.
Illuminating, well-researched and vital. Documentaries like Tapped come along every once in a while to raise awareness, to inform the public and to clear the fog of propaganda.
A refreshingly imaginative, funny and intelligent sci-fi drama boasting a superb performance by Paul Giamatti.
Equally thought-provoking, funny, sweet and tender.
A mildly engaging, low-key drama that's somewhat lazy, bland and ultimately underwhelming.
An engrossing, tender and compelling drama boasting exquisite cinematography and a radiant performance by the beautiful Ozgu Namal.
A magical, uplifting and visually stunning film that's exhilarating for kids and adults simultaneously.

Picturesque cinematography along with charming performances by Eric Bana and the genuinely beautiful Rachel McAdams [don't] compensate for an uneven, bland and contrived screenplay that falls flat when it comes to drama, romance and sci-fi.
Outrageous, crass and occasionally funny with a lively ensemble cast, but its humor often feels uninspired, lazy, asinine and ultimately forgettable.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mildly engaging with slick cinematography and a sexy cast, but it's often like its protagonist himself: superficial, shallow, lazy and lacking an emotional core.
Initially suspenseful and has a sexy cast and beautiful scenery that provides lots of eye candy, but the suspense and intrigue fizzle out when its "whodunit" mystery ends during the hour mark...

Has stylish cinematography, terrific sound editing and other solid production values, but it suffers from excessive style over substance...It leaves you feeling unenlightened and, ultimately, undewhelmed.
An initially intriguing, well-shot psychological drama with diminishing suspense. It eventually starts to drag, leaving you feeling concurrently frustrated and underwhelmed.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sensationally entertaining, relentlessly suspenseful and thrilling with a terrific ensemble cast and wickedly funny and witty dialogue. Tarantino fans rejoice!
Has fleeting moments of excitement and thrills, but too often veers into silliness, inanity and blandness while ultimately failing to entertain older and younger audiences simultaneously.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Often drags and falls flat as a stale, contrived drama and painfully unfunny comedy with forgettable, cardboard characters.
Has stunning 3D visuals which briefly provide a rush of adrenaline, but it often feels too dull while lacking insight and suspense as well as palpable excitement.
Unpredictable and mildly engaging with decent performances, but suffers from an uneven balance of dark comedy, drama and satire with too much awkwardness and not enough bite.
Loses steam toward the end, but, nonetheless, manages to be a fascinating and heartfelt drama filled with suspense, intrigue and lush cinematography.
Boasts a charming cast and superb production design along with briefly amusing and heartfelt moments which get bogged down by bland dialogue and an unfocused plot that often meanders.
A 90-minute tour de force of suspense and intrigue with outstanding, powerhouse performances by James Nesbitt and Liam Neeson. It's one of the most rousing and provocative thrillers of the year.
Brave, provocative and deeply poignant with a raw and heartfelt performance by Ursula Werner. It's easily one of the most powerfully emotional films of the year.
Occasionally drags, but offers a relentlessly stark glimpse into the morbid, tragic life of two lost souls who haven't found happiness or prosperity.

Occasionally drags, but boasts a raw, emotionally complex performance by Arta Dobroshi. It's a quietly moving, character-driven drama with a heightened sense of devastating realism and genuine suspense, which only begin to wane toward the end.
A bold, captivating, riveting and well-edited documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually as well as emotionally.
Boasts a terrific ensemble cast, occasional thrills and spectacular visuals, but it suffers from a less-than-spectacular plot that's often contrived, uneven in tone and anticlimactic.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshingly sweet, charming and heartfelt romantic comedy with just the right combination of wit, humor and tenderness.
Captivating and emotionally resonating with a powerfully raw performance by Nina Hoss.
movie_title: Anonyma - Eine Frau in Berlin (A Woman in Berlin) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A heartfelt, mildly fascinating documentary that lacks sufficient insight to keep you thoroughly intrigued and enlightened.
A captivating, poignant and inspirational documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them intellectually.
Too lazy, preposterous and inane to even be considered as a guilty pleasure.
Mildly engaging, but often contrived and dull with stilted dialogue that lacks much-needed pizzazz.
A crass, simple-minded and highly contrived R-rated comedy that's nonetheless outrageously funny and irresistibly entertaining.
