Occasionally sinks into ludicrousness, but has enough suspense, chills and surprises to keep avid horror fans viscerally compelled and ultimately satisfied.
A deceptively simple indie drama that's quite bizarre, raw, haunting and refreshingly original on a visceral level.
A mildly engaging ensemble drama with decent performances, but it suffers from an overstuffed, contrived and often tedious plot that fails to pack any palpable, emotional punches.
A provocative, taut and compelling documentary that's concurrently disturbing and profoundly moving.
Has a terrific cast and charming performances, but it's often lazy, contrived, lacking insight and, ultimately, underwhelming in terms of drama, romance and comedy.
A provocative, non-preachy, vital and illuminating documentary with quietly powerful and haunting images.
Surreal and absurd, yet oddly captivating and filled with a dry, sardonic sense of humor, stunning visuals along with provocative critiques of modern society.

Has a few laughs and a terrific ensemble cast, but suffers from an uninspired, unfocused screenplay, boring characters and too many contrived moments, it often drags and utlimately falls flat as a drama, comedy and romance
A sensationally entertaining, well-researched documentary filled with insight and outrageously funny clips.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Offers plenty of gore and stylish cinematography, but no imagination, surprises or intrigue. Ultimately, it's tedious, inane and increasingly preposterous, even if you're willing to suspend your disbelief and to check your brain at the door for 88 minutes
A captivating, engrossing and character-driven thriller filled with solid performances along with palpable suspense, intensity and intrigue.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Initially intriguing, but tepid romantic drama suffering from an uneven screenplay with stilted dialogue and a distracting, gimmicky ghost story.

Initially invigorating, chilling and mildly suspenseful while balanced with just the right amount of dark comedy, but it occasionally veers into a tedium of awkwardness and over-the-top bizarreness that lacks surprises.
A simply complex, intelligent and quietly absorbing drama with just the right blend of humor, tenderness and cinéma vérité realism.
Poignant, but ultimately underwhelming and lacking insight.
Pretentious, tedious, dumb, pointless and, worst of all, boring. Avoid it like the plague, and go watch Kill Bill or Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon again instead.
A sweeping and captivating film that offers both style and substance.
Lazy, repetitive, underdeveloped, forced and bland. If you're a big fan of the first film, prepare to be very disappointed.
Fans of 70s sexploitation films will feel as though they've stepped into a time warp as they observe the impressive production design.
A fair and balanced exposé. Prepare to be enlightened, alarmed, and enraged.
An engrossing, captivating drama grounded in humanism and bolstered by a charismatic, convincingly moving performance by Emory Cohen, a national treasure.
Fascinating, timely and provocative.
movie_title: Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An engrossing, unflinchingly honest drama that showcases Paprika Steen's haunting, brave and tour de force performance.
Candid, brave and moving, but it leaves too many unanswered questions that might have been asked by an unbiased filmmaker with more distance from the Kirschenbaum family.
One of the most powerful, heartfelt and tender films since Boys Don't Cry.
Well-acted and refreshingly heartfelt despite excessive exposition, stuffiness, and a few implausibilities.
Outrageously funny and captivating, but ultimately undercooked. Sally Field knocks it out of the ballpark with one of the best performances of her career.
Mildly entertaining and slickly-directed, but uneven and not clever or exhilarating enough.
Poignant, offbeat and visually striking, but occasionally drags and overstays its welcome.
Harmless, uplifting and heartwarming withing being cloying.
A thoroughly fascinating, captivating, well-edited and provocative documentary. It should be mandatory viewing for anyone even remotely interested in politics and history.
Dull, overlong, exhausting and mildly entertaining without rising to the heights of the first Captain America's palpable thrills, suspense and intrigue
A lean, gripping, exhilarating and refreshingly intelligent thriller.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Increasingly implausible, uneven and lethargic despite solid performances from its talented actors.
Bold, raunchy and biting, Jimmy Vestvood is one of the most outrageously funny comedies in years.
A wildly entertaining albeit convoluted dark comedy with witty, funny and crackling dialogue and palpable chemistry Crowe and Gosling.
Thoroughly captivating, alarming, gripping and poignant
Thrilling and visually dazzling, but lacks the book's heart and soul.
Over-the-top and irritating without being funny or clever enough. If only the audience were to have as much fun as the actors seemed to be having.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Witty, charming and delightful. Catherine Frot is at her best with a charismatic, heartfelt performance.
Refreshingly well-balanced, Illuminating, provocative, vital and engaging. You'll never look at Zionism the same way again.

Profound, haunting, tender, warm, captivating, intelligent and brimming with humanism from start to finish. Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay give well-nuanced performances and find the emotional truths of their roles with conviction.
Stilted, undercooked and shallow despite its promising premise.
Relatable, engrossing, sweet and tender. It's one of the best romantic dramas since Before Sunrise.
A captivating, well-directed and timely drama with a radiant breakthrough performance by Jessica Rothe.
A briskly-edited, fascinating and awe-inspiring introduction to the Land Art of the 1960's and 70's.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Well-acted and initially suspenseful before it turns increasingly implausible, lazy and uninspired as it piles on the twists in unsatisfying ways.
Exhilarating and intense on a visceral level. It's as powerful as The Hurt Locker, and the most mature, emotionally-charged blockbuster of Michael Bay's career.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully shot, refreshingly offbeat, captivating and unflinching while remaining grounded in humanism.
movie_title: Bleak Street (La calle de la amargura) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Illuminating, potent, fair and balanced. Enraging yet hopeful. One of the best documentaries of the year. It's important that you watch it for the sake of democracy.
A breezy and uplifting film that sparkles with a charismatic performance by Cecilia So.
Thrilling, suspenseful and captivating while remaining grounded in humanism. Holliday Grainger gives a truly radiant breakthrough performance. It's the first must-see movie of 2016.
A refreshingly heartfelt, warm and tender film.
A wildly entertaining, outrageously funny action comedy.
Mesmerizing, breathtaking and quietly poignant with a delicate blend of drama and comic relief.
An exhilarating, amusing and crowd-pleasing action comedy that's filled with infectious fun.
movie_title: From Vegas To Macau 3 (From Vegas To Macau Iii) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Action-packed, mildly exhilarating and over-produced with plenty of visual pizzazz in 3D.
movie_title: The Monkey King 2 (San Da Bai Gu Jing) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful, gripping, provocative and heartfelt. It's a thinking person's war film.
Mysterious, breathtaking, wondrous, lyrical, captivating and profound. Patient and intellectual audiences will be rewarded the most.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Slight and ultimately suffers from excessive style and shallow interviews while lacking balance and compelling insight.
A winning combination of comedy, drama, suspense and thrills that will delight kids and adults alike. It's a potent reminder that we're in a Golden Age of Animation.
Lean, terrifying and chilling with nail-biting suspense. It will scare the living daylights out of you!
Sumptuous, dazzling visuals along with some campiness and captivating performances compensate for emotional hollowness, a dull narrative and lack of substance.
Thrilling, exciting and dazzling with a heartbeat underneath. Star Wars: The Force Awakens delivers everything you want in a Star Wars movie. It's worth waiting in line for, and lives up to the hype.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Absorbing, provocative and refreshingly unHollywood. Shira Hass gives a bravura performance.
Warm, witty, tender and genuinely uplifting. A triumph!
Vital, eye-opening and hopeful.
A fine introduction to the life and work of Floyd Norman, but it merely scratches the surface.
The best underdog sports movies since The Blind Side. It will make you stand up and cheer!
Engrossing, wise, funny and well-acted. How refreshing it is to watch an American film that's for adults, that can't be turned into a video game. and where no one gets eaten by zombies for a change!
If only Hollywood's blockbusters could be even half as gripping, smart and emotionally engrossing as Tunnel!
Clunky, lazy, stilted and implausible. It might as well take place on another planet. Its running time of 80 minutes feels more like 2 hours.
An effective blend of drama, mystery, horror, dark comedy and sci-fi. It deserves to become a cult classic
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Overstuffed, undercooked and corny despite its stellar cast. It's almost as cringe-worthy, clunky and painfully contrived as The Family Stone.
Heartbreaking, surprising and thrilling. Be prepared to be haunted by the powerful ending.
Electrifying and enlightening. It will captivate and nourish the minds and souls of audiences both young and old
movie_title: Dying To Know: Ram Dass & Timothy Leary (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Slick, but too shallow, uneven and implausible.
Spectacular visual effects with a few thrilling scenes, but mostly overlong and tedious. It's just as dull, cringe-inducing and disappointing as Indiana Jones and the Crystal Skull.
Profound and refreshingly unconventional doc that will nourish your mind and soul.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: No less dull, shallow and forgettable than your average direct-to-VOD Sci-fi thriller, but with a bigger budget and A-list cast.
An intriguing, Kaufmanesque premise that's poorly executed. It's tedious, dull and exhausting instead of being a wildly entertaining mind-f*ck like The Science of Sleep or Inception.
A quietly moving, breathtaking and captivating war film that's grounded in humanism and trusts the audience's patience and emotions.
Insightful, timely, provocative and enraging, but a bit dry rather than cinematic at times.
Spellbinding, gripping and eye-opening. Bravo to directors Darrin Fletcher and Chet Thomas for bringing Tim Ballard and the human rights issue of child sex trafficking to light.
Exhilarating, moving, illuminating and, ultimately, inspirational. You don't have to be a dance aficionado to appreciate it.
A genuinely heartfelt, mesmerizing and breathtaking love story brimming with humanism. It will nourish your heart and soul.
An exhilarating, taut, slick and intelligent crime thriller.
A rousing, thrilling, and exhilarating epic in spite of the lethargic, stilted drama during its first hour. Morgan Freeman shows up as Ilderim to rescue both Ben-Hur and the film as well.
A sweet, slick, harmless and pleasantly diverting romantic dramedy. There have been better remakes in the past, and there have been worse.
An outrageously thrilling, witty, fast-paced and amusing adventure.
As lethargic, stilted and clunky as a bad made-for-TV movie despite strong performances by Colin Firth and Jude law.
Warm, intimate and irresistibly entertaining.
Funny, genuinely poignant, and thrilling with dazzling CGI. It will win your heart over. Expect it to be nominated for Best Animated Feature.
An irresistibly captivating, funny and witty roller coaster ride.
A lean, riveting and gritty thriller.
Dazzling CGI and a breakthrough performance by Ruby Barnhill, but the film is unevenly paced, clunky and lacks warm, wit and cleverness.
Quietly powerful, poignant, well-acted and captivating
Strong performances compensate for an uneven blend of comedy, tragedy and drama along with contrivances. You can feel the wheels of the screenplay turning.
Insightful and candid, but frustrating, dizzying fast-paced editing.
Gripping, captivating and electrifying. Bryan Cranston gives one of the best performances of his career.
A searing, powerful and persuasive exposé. Consider it your patriotic duty to see it! You'll never look at Hillary Clinton the same way again.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful, poignant and illuminating. It will keep you at the edge of your seat.
A lean, gripping, well-acted and creepy psychological horror film. Kudos to the filmmakers for trusting the audience's imagination.
A mostly underwhelming, lethargic doc that leaves you with more questions than answers.
movie_title: Hieronymus Bosch, Touched by the Devil (Jheronimus Bosch, Touched By The Devil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Well-edited and shot, but ultimately underwhelming and forgettable while suffering from style over substance
Tackles a vital and provocative question, without a variety of different answers, it feels incomplete and unbalanced.
A dazzling, rousing and exhilarating visual spectacle. More fun and breathtaking than Gods of Egypt.
A vapid, soulless, tedious and painfully boring blockbuster. A contender for one of the worst films of the year. I'm surprised it wasn't directed by Alan Smithee.
An intelligent, nuanced, slow-burning Hitchcockian thriller. It deserves to be a sleeper hit.
Strong, heartfelt performances barely compensate for the dull screenplay. It ultimately lacks the magic of the classic children's book.

Given that we're in a Golden Age of Documentaries, it's disappointing that this doc doesn't live up to its potential by lacking insight and being somewhat lethargic as well as overlong despite its brief running time.
Heartfelt, but slightly repetitive and not balanced or analytical enough. It ultimately preaches to the choir.
Intimate, revealing and heartbreaking.
A timely doc that opens up a lot of issues for post-discussion. You'll never look at a hijab the same way again.
Heartfelt, tender, engaging and relatable with a charismatic performance by Vivian Sung.
Lively, witty and captivating with a few interesting kernels of wisdom, but not particularly profound, surprising or truly revelatory.
An enigmatic, slow-burn with striking visuals, but often confusing and frustrating while suffering from style over substance.
Effectively droll, surreal, intelligent and exquisitely-shot, but somewhat repetitive and not as captivating as Andersson's prior films.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Campy, silly, wickedly funny, brilliantly bizarre and refreshingly original. It's best experienced while drinking a few beers.
Shallow, overlong, unimaginative and lackluster. It's yet another disappointing Hollywood blockbuster.
A contrived, clunky biopic that often drags and fails to pack any emotional punches.
Groundbreaking! Shocking! Unlike any documentary you've seen before! An eye-opening, provocative stepping stone for debate and critical thinking. You'll be talking about it for weeks!
Smart, funny, thrilling, imaginative, inspired and exhilarating, Inside Out is everything you want a Pixar movie to be, and more. It's destined to become a new animated classic.
An intelligent, sophisticated and mesmerizing slow-burn thriller that's grounded in humanism. Patient viewers will be rewarded the most.

Lyrical and elliptical, but often confusing with awkward editing and a non-linear structure that deflates its dramatic momentum. Even Jennifer Connelly's convincingly moving performance can't save the film.
A silly, campy, delightfully implausible and unrepentant B-movie. If you liked Samuel L. Jackson in Snakes on a Plane and Kingsman, you'll love him in this!
A compelling, occasionally intriguing crime thriller that's refreshingly grounded in humanism, but it loses its emotional footing during its twisty third act.
Well-edited, witty, poignant and funny. It finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally.
Unfocused and lacking insight, but it's at least entertaining thanks to its witty, quirky subject.
A delightful, toe-tapping and illuminating tribute to Sophie Tucker.
Aimless and dull with half-baked ideas. It would've worked better as a short.
A taut, atmospheric, engrossing and slow-burning noir thriller with a radiant performance by Nina Hoss.
Funny, witty and delightful. Kids will love it!
It's just as equally entertaining and provocative as Vidal and Buckley's debates.
An exhilarating blend of action, intrigue, suspense and comic relief. Tom Cruise still has the knack of being a charismatic leading man.
Bold and well-acted, but undercooked, lackluster and overlong. It ultimately bites off more than it can chew.
A mindless, expensive B-movie that's more exhausting, tedious and nauseating than exhilarating.

A breathtaking, enlightening and powerful ode to the vital symbiosis of man and nature. It will nourish your mind, body and soul. One of the most powerful and inspiring documentaries since An Inconvenient Truth!
An amusing screwball comedy with a refreshingly complex female lead, but unevenly blended with drama at times.
Heartfelt, but a squandered opportunity to insightfully tackle an important human rights issue.
Compelling, honest and refreshingly un-Hollywood. It's proof that strong roles for women do indeed exist if you look beyond Hollywood.
Sweeping, witty, delightful and charming while brimming with warmth and humanism.
Funny, heartfelt and inspirational. The best high school comedy since Easy A. Mae Whitman deserves to be a star.
A wickedly funny, perceptive and smart roller coaster ride of emotions that walks a fine line between comedy and tragedy.
A genuinely heartfelt and delightful crowd-pleaser that will make your spirit soar.
Warm, emotionally resonating and quietly powerful with tender, natural performances.
Eye-opening, vital and refreshingly well-balanced. It will change the way you look at heart attacks forever.
A mildly insightful and intimate peak behind the curtain, but it's ultimately more potatoes than meat.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A slick, entertaining albeit somewhat slight date movie.
Well-acted with a compelling concept, but shallow and less than the sum of its parts.
Somber, emotionally engaging and haunting with exquisite, awards-worthy cinematography, set design and costume design.
Campy, dumb, silly and outrageous---the vein of a Roger Corman film.
An important, emotionally engrossing and well-edited documentary about the true heroes of Italy during WWII.
movie_title: My Italian Secret: The Forgotten Heroes (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A tedious, vapid and over-produced bore that will surely please the shallow masses who are unashamedly entertained by bread and circuses.
Picturesque scenery, exquisite set/costume designs and solid performances fail to enliven the film which lacks subtlety, often drags and ultimately fails to pack enough of an emotional wallop.
If you're looking for an intelligent, atmospheric, slow-burning crime drama that's anti-Hollywood, Black Souls won't disappoint you.
Sophisticated, profound, tender and well-acted. It's far better than the overrated Birdman.
Suspenseful with moving performances, but suffers from a pedestrian, Hollywood-style screenplay and brisk pacing that doesn't give the film enough room to breathe nor does it trust your patience.
A heartwarming and superbly-acted drama that hits all the right emotional notes.
Refreshingly non-judgmental and engaging on a visceral level, but low on insight and humanizing background info about its subjects.
A refreshing, fun, imaginative and amusing comedy worth seeing with a large audience.
Fascinating. A must-see for all aspiring filmmakers.
A gripping and exhilarating thriller! Nicholas Cage is in top form! It's his best performance since Leaving Las Vegas.
Too scary and intense for kids, but adults will be mildly captivated.
Dazzling to look at with awe-inspiring standard effects (read: CGI) , but it lacks enough truly special effects, a.k.a. humanism.
A powerful, enraging and heartbreaking exposé.
Spellbinding, suspenseful and emotionally devastating. It's one of the most powerful Holocaust films since Schindler's List.
Well-edited, well-balanced and frightening.
Heartfelt performances and breathtaking scenery barely compensate for the pedestrian screenplay's shortcomings.
A fair and balanced call to action that sheds light on a rarely-documented animal rights issue. Prepare to enraged, shocked and horrified.
A wickedly funny, clever, refreshingly inventive and crowd-pleasing satire that's destined to become a cult classic.
Fascinating and bold, but incomplete without enough thorough analysis. The verdict is still out there.
Profoundly moving, inspirational and uplifting. It will restore your faith in humanity.
A well-acted dramedy that's heartfelt, funny and refreshingly witty.
A highly entertaining peak behind the curtain of Tab Hunter, a charismatic, warm, wise and honest subject.
Powerful, haunting and provocative. Equally spellbinding, breathtaking and disturbing. It should be mandatory viewing for all Chileans.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A tender, well-acted drama brimming with warmth and humanism.
Mysterious, bizarre and somewhat inventive with a quirky Jean-Pierre Jeunet-vibe, but it often drags.
Slightly repetitive and overlong, but essential viewing for all aspiring medical doctors.
Gently moving with raw performances by Geraldine Chaplin and Yanet Mojica and a quietly powerful and haunting ending that compensate for lack of depth in the screenplay.
Fun, peppy and diverting with a charismatic cast.
Riveting, fascinating, fair and balanced with unprecedented behind-the-scenes access.
Mesmerizing and emotionally engrossing with a bravura performance by Eddie Redmayne. One of the best films of 2015.
Over-produced with a stilted, silly screenplay and an over-the-top performance by James McAvoy. Can I get some cheese to go with all that ham?
A tender, heartfelt tearjerker that genuinely earns its tears. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give Oscar-worthy performances. Don't be surprised if you see it on many Top 10 lists.
Electrifying, provocative and profoundly moving. Andrew Garfield and Michael Shannon give Oscar-caliber performances.
Fine performances, especially from Johnny Depp, barely compensate for an undercooked, pedestrian screenplay overstuffed with too many poorly developed characters
Spellbinding, suspenseful and provocative. It's one of the most powerful films since The Thin Blue Line.
Equally enlightening, entertaining and moving. Well-edited, uplifting and inspirational!
Light, breezy, mildly amusing and somewhat silly at times. Bernadette Lafont gives a lively, engaging performance.
Prepare to be emotionally engrossed and enraged by this alarming and searing exposé on neocolonialism in South Sudan.
Riveting, breathtaking and inspirational. It joins To the Limit and Touching the Void as another essential mountain climbing doc that's a must-see on the big screen.
A slick, stylishly-edited doc that manages to be illuminating and easy-to-follow.
A hilarious, thrilling and exhilarating ride that's destined to become a cult classic.
Exciting action scenes and stunning visuals, but overlong, somewhat exhausting and overstuffed with too many forgettable characters. Less would have been more.
A well-edited, well-organized and heartfelt doc that provides hope for anyone dealing with PTSD.
movie_title: Searching for Home, Coming Back From War (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Well-edited, balanced and fascinating.
Warm, wise, tender and profoundly human. It's an uplifting crowd-pleaser that earns every moment of uplift. Regina Casé deserves an Oscar.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Quietly suspenseful. It works best as a simple cautionary tale against seductive con artists.

Occasionally preachy and oversimplified, yet captivating, tender and heartfelt. It can lead to many interesting discussions if you open your mind and heart to it, and forgive its preachiness. Karen Abercrombie gives an emotionally radiant performance.
An important, timely and captivating doc.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A sizzling, action-packed thrill ride and a pure rush of adrenaline! Ed Skrein is a charismatic, debonair actor star.
Hilarious, zany and fun. Prepare to be delighted.
Slick and mildly provocative, but overlong with excessive expository information. Steve Jobs makes for a very captivating subject.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Equally tender, heartwarming, relatable and inspirational while remaining a captivating, exhilarating and thrilling experience.
Emotionally gripping, somber, well-acted and brimming with humanism.
A captivating and illuminating introduction to a fascinating artist who deserves to be more widely known.
The first masterpiece of 2015. Spellbinding, lyrical and breathtaking. Epic in scope while intimate in its humanism. I could have watched 4 more hours.
movie_title: Home from Home: Chronicle of a Vision (Die Andere Heimat) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A captivating, fascinating and breathtaking documentary that will open your heart, mind and soul the wonders of Durga Puja.
An enchanting romantic drama that would make for a perfect date night.
Yet another disappointingly lazy horror film that lacks scares, imagination and cleverness. It should have gone straight to VOD. Can we please call a moratorium on found footage horror films?
A bold, imaginative and refreshingly diverting "documentary" that's occasionally uneven in tone, and most fun and clever when it doesn't take itself too seriously.

Warm, heartfelt and uplifting despite a cloying and contrived screenplay. Mira Nair is the perfect director for such a film because her films are always brimming with humanism, a truly special effect.
Anemic, overlong, and suffers from too much style over substance.
Mesmerizing, heartfelt and powerful with an Oscar-worthy performance by Karolina Gruszka. It's one of the best films of the year. Marie Curie is a true "Wonder Woman."
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pedestrian, monotonous, dull and exhausting despite strong performances.
Poorly edited, underwhelming, and dull, although it does have beautiful images of nature.
movie_title: Look & See: A Portrait of Wendell Berry (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Refreshingly amusing, unbiased, and captivating
A witty, wickedly funny and razor sharp blend of comedy, politics and drama with fine performances by Timothy Spall and Colm Meaney.
Mildly engaging and intriguing with a solid performance by the charismatic, underrated Kerry Fox.
One of the most heartfelt and enlightening documentaries of the year. It should be mandatory for all soldiers to watch it prior to enlistment.
Stodgy, convoluted and cold with excessive style over substance.
A gut-wrenching, horrifying, unflinching and disturbing experience. Gripping, moving and, above all, profoundly human.
Captivating, enchanting, and whimsical, Footnotes is one of the year's most delightful surprises.
Suspenseful, shocking and thrilling.
Captivating, engrossing and genuinely heartfelt before becoming contrived toward the end, but Frot and Deneuve keep the film constantly afloat with their stellar performances and charisma.
A beautifully shot, shallow, and nauseating video game. Too much Spectacle and not nearly enough humanism, a truly special effect that money cannot buy. It's the equivalent of dry, stale bread.
An enraging, heartbreaking, and eye-opening exposé.
Quietly moving albeit slightly meandering with rich, complex characters, and exquisite cinematography. It does demand a lot of your patience, but patience, after all, can be rewarding.
Quietly moving, provocative, and refreshingly understated. It's the most wise and visually striking film since La Sapienza.
Haunting, engrossing, and poetic with mesmerizing, beautifully-shot scenery reminiscent of the films of Carlos Reygadas.
movie_title: I Dream in Another Language (Sueño en otro idioma) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Underwhelming, unfocused, and lacking insight.
A moving, unflinching drama with raw performances by Bérénice Bejo and Cédric Kahn.
An exciting, fast-paced ride filled with palpable thrills. A rush of pure adrenaline. Escapist fun!
Slick and well-edited with a captivating rags-to-riches story, but it's too busy exalting John Paul DeJoria to profoundly explore its themes or to ask intriguing questions.
Shallow and dull. Stylish cinematography and editing alone, sans any substance, do not make a doc even remotely great. It's one of the most disappointing documentaries of the year.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Insightful and occasionally mesmerizing, but lacks balance and thoroughness.
A taut crime thriller with just the right blend of action, suspense, and pathos.
Captivating, exciting and intriguing with edge-of-your-seat suspense. It's the best Asian crime thriller since Infernal Affairs.
Unflinching, heart-wrenching, and illuminating.
movie_title: Angkor Awakens: A Portrait of Cambodia (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Witty and outrageously funny. One of the most entertaining, provocative and original sci-fi films of the year. Ela Thier gives a spirited performance.
Joseph Hader breathes life into his role with a raw, understated performance that somewhat compensates for the screenplay's lack of emotional depth.
Great costume design and visual effects, but overlong, exhausting, and dull with nauseating choppy editing.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A witty, sparkling and captivating romantic comedy full of surprises.
Well-shot and mildly compelling with a strong performance by Boguslaw Linda that rises above the stodgy screenplay and monotonous tone.
Lethargic, meandering, overstuffed and undercooked with decent performances that fail to invigorate the material.
An intriguing, taut sci-fi crime thriller with a labyrinthian plot.
A crowd-pleasing, charming delight brimming with genuine warmth, wit, humor, and tenderness. If only more films were to have such rich and lively roles for older women! It's a cause for celebration!
It has a few thrilling action sequences, but it's often loud, dumb, exhausting and, most unfortunately, lacks the wit, excitement and fun that made the first Pirates of the Caribbean so entertaining.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Enthralling, suspenseful, thrilling and refreshingly witty. A much-needed breath of fresh air. Bravo to Patty Jenkins! Note to Hollywood: please hire more women to direct blockbusters.
Refreshingly inventive, wildly entertaining with genuine poignancy and dazzling visuals. It has both style and substance.
A compelling, moving and gently suspenseful tapestry of dysfunctional lives.
Searing, enraging, and eye-opening. You will never look at the mainstream media nor the CIA the same way again. Consider it your patriotic duty to see it.
movie_title: American Media & The Second Assassination of John F. Kennedy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Searing, enraging, and eye-opening. You will never look at the mainstream media nor the CIA the same way again. Consider it your patriotic duty to see it
movie_title: The American Media and the 2nd Assassination of President John F. Kennedy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mesmerizing, illuminating, and a must-see for film and history buffs.
Great visual effects and musical score, but it falls flat with dullness while being too low on wit and humor. Sometimes the third time's the charm, but that's not the case with Cars 3 .
Pedestrian and disappointingly underwhelming with chopping editing. It bites off much more than it could chew.
Illuminating, but too one-sided and unpersuasive for skeptics.
An underwhelming and lethargic drama that can't be saved by its strong performances.
An emotionally resonating, mesmerizing, and haunting drama that offers both style and substance.
A heartbreaking, enraging and eye-opening experience, but limited in scope.
An exhilarating, funny, and thrilling ride. It's one of the best action comedies since Lethal Weapon and Rush Hour.
Slightly underwhelming and lacking profundity, but Anton Yelchin's tender, nuanced, and moving performance along with the visually poetic cinematography compensate for the lack of substance.
An enormously entertaining film filled with plenty of delightful thrills, humor, wit, and pathos. Kids will love it. It's among the best animated films of 2017.
An exhilarating and enchanting adventure with just the right blend of humor and heart. A perfect holiday treat for the entire family!
Sobering, heartbreaking and visually stylish, but limited in scope.
Sporadically thrilling, but overlong, exhausting, tonally uneven, and often dull.
Enchanting, intelligent, tender, and profoundly human with a perfect balance of Truth and Spectacle. One of the best films of the year!

A toothless, lackluster, and underwhelming satire that's less than the sum of its parts. It's a great idea, poorly executed. That said, Hong Chau gives a radiant, breakthrough performance that will put her on the map.
Mildly engaging, but lazy and inane with very few scares, little suspense, and no surprises. The charismatic Lin Shaye is its only asset. She deserves a far better screenplay.
Provocative, but scattershot, and low on insight as well as analysis. It bites off much more than it can chew and would be more fitting as supplemental, introductory material.
It has plenty of atmosphere, but not nearly enough scares or imagination.
movie_title: The Tag-Along 2 (Hong yi xiao nu hai 2) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Unflinching, disturbing, and refreshingly un-Hollywood. It makes The Florida Project look like a Disney movie.

Contrived with stilted, clunky dialogue and intrusive music, but it's nonetheless engaging and uplifting sans dullness and schmaltz. Thora Birch gives a tender, nuanced performance that exudes charisma. She's just as radiant as Leslie Caron was in Gigi.

Lazy, vapid, unsexy, mind-numbing and poorly edited. A reminder of how far we've come from the Golden Age of American Cinema. It leaves you feeling nothing but relieved that the series is officially over.
A stylish, but increasingly pretentious and preposterous mindf*&k.
An insipid, soulless, and overproduced bore.

A rousing crime thriller that arrives at just the right time during the #MeToo movement to serve as a form of much-needed catharsis. If you loved The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, you'll also love Red Sparrow.
Mildly engaging with great cinematography, but overstuffed, undercooked, contrived, shallow, and somewhat lethargic.

Mesmerizing, gripping, and profoundly moving. Charlotte Rampling gives a heartfelt, nuanced performance reminiscent of Delphine Serig's understated performance in JEANNE DIELMAN. It's one of the best films of the year thus far.
Big-hearted with awe-inspiring CGI, but suffers from a corny, preachy, dull, and clunky screenplay with overbearing music that doesn't trust the audience's emotions enough.
Suspenseful and captivating albeit not as unflinchingly horrifying as it could have been.
Occasionally thrilling, but mostly exhausting, dull, and shallow. It's yet another mindless, soulless, and overlong blockbuster that's high on Spectacle and too low on Truth.
Mesmerizing, quietly moving, and enthralling. It's one of the best films of the year.
Enormously entertaining. Witty, funny, delightfully campy, and irreverent. A great time at the movies.
A provocative, emotionally resonant, and powerful drama. Melissa Leo gives a commanding, tour de force performance. Margaret Qualley is radiant.
Intense, but tedious and ultimately fails to get inside the head of any of its characters.
A captivating, provocative, and refreshingly well-balanced documentary that's equally heartbreaking, disturbing, and enraging.
Emotionally powerful and mesmerizing. As profoundly moving, haunting and spellbinding as Shoah. One of the best documentaries of the year.
A mesmerizing, heartfelt and fascinating film that would make a compelling Hollywood biopic.
A slow-burning, atmospheric drama. One of the most mesmerizing and haunting American films since Beasts of the Southern Wild.
A well-acted, but overlong, clunky, and underwhelming satire.
movie_title: The Queen of Spain (La reina de España) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's like a bad student film made by someone who's trying to emulate the great directors of classic mindf*cks without understanding what made those classics so great to begin with. A sure-fire awards contender----at the Razzies!
Jesper Christensen gives an effectively commanding that rises above the dry, pedestrian screenplay.
Taut, intriguing, and engrossing. A cross between Seven, Memento, Heat and Insomnia.
Outrageous and unpredictable albeit silly and lowbrow.

Captivating, witty and unforgettable. A powerful, moving and haunting character study. One of the best satires of Hollywood since The Player and What Just Happened. Emmett Hughes gives a breakthrough performance.
Heartbreaking and gripping, but repetitive and not broad enough in scope.
Stylishly shot in black-and-white, well-acted, and unflinchingly grim, but it's exhausting, overlong, and ultimately underwhelming.
Breezy, charming, and delightfully amusing albeit repetitive.
A smart, wickedly funny, and biting satire that deserves to become a cult classic.
Moving, captivating, and beautifully-shot.
Without style or substance, it's one of the most boring docs of the year.
A mildly engaging, action-packed crime thriller.
Chilling, provocative, and mesmerizing. It's one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Profoundly moving, warm, and captivating. A truly remarkable and unforgettable documentary.
Bold, bizarre, and outrageously funny, but repetitive and occasionally drags.
Captivating and emotionally gritty with a raw, commanding performance by Nikolaj Coster-Waldau.

Loud, shallow, mindless, slightly overlong and soulless, but so what? At least it still has plenty of eye candy, a little bit of wit, and a giddy, self-deprecating sense of humor intact which makes it entertaining on a purely visceral level.
Warm, candid, illuminating, and enormously entertaining.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Overstuffed and undercooked, but it's saved by the natural performances by Alex Ozerov and Sasha K. Gordon who add some emotional depth.
Equally insightful, enraging and poignant. The most powerful, life-altering documentary since Food, Inc.
A smart, sophisticated and riveting psychological thriller for adults. Isabelle Hupper's best role since The Piano Teacher!
A profound, heartfelt and outrageously funny emotional journey. It's one of the best films of the year.
Everything you want an underdog story to be: suspenseful, inspirational, heartfelt and, ultimately, uplifting. It will make you stand up and cheer! A slam dunk!
Bold, zany and outrageously funny. The most wildly original comedy since Being John Malkovich. It's a godsend!
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It suffers, like many blockbusters, from too much spectacle and not enough truth, but its greatest sin is that it feels dull, insipid and underwhelming despite a plethora of loud action scenes and dazzling visual effects.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Raw, heartfelt, well-acted and exhilarating. A refreshingly unpredictable, imaginative, and un-Hollywood film that has just the right balance of truth and spectacle.
Filled with useful and essential information that could inspire you to become a vegetarian or vegan and to steer clear of any food product that has more than a few ingredients in its label.
Potent, hopeful and enlightening. It can change the way you think about at the world and the symbiosis of man and nature.
A winning combination of action, comedy, musical, adventure and drama. The best family film of the holiday season!
Mildly engaging, but not nearly as powerful or illuminating as Lost Boys of Sudan.
movie_title: Ghostland: The View of the Ju'Hoansi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Annette Bening gives a radiant, tour de force performance in a simultaneously overstuffed and undercooked film with a dishonest, oversimplified third act.
Provocative, accessible and refreshingly fair and balanced.

A mildly gripping, pedestrian thriller elevated by terrific performances by the always-reliable Emma Thompson and Brendan Gleeson and by the inspirational story of two ordinary citizens who bravely refused to remain Good Germans.
Powerful, engrossing and provocative with just the right blend of truth and spectacle. It's the rare kind of film that has a heart, mind and soul intact.
Its very thought-provoking, timely content and compelling subject compensate for its deficiencies.
movie_title: Accidental Courtesy: Daryl Davis, Race & America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mindlessly entertaining and unashamedly shallow. It's a rush of pure adrenaline that's best experienced on the big screen.
Equally enchanting, poetic, sad, breathtaking and mesmerizing. It's among the best Animated films in recent years.
Heartbreaking, but often tedious and not thorough, enraging nor illuminating enough.
Eye-opening, heartfelt and illuminating.
Equally heartwarming and heartbreaking. A testament to the humanism of writer/director Ken Loach
Equally breathtaking and tragic. A powerful wake up call for all of mankind to embrace and appreciate nature instead of destroying it. Patient audiences will be rewarded the most.
Mildly engaging with a talented, charismatic cast, but it's overstuffed and suffers from the ailment that most blockbusters suffer from: too much spectacle and not enough truth.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling documentary with a fascinating, heartbreaking story.
The most essential, illuminating and enraging film since Food, Inc.
Not as powerful as Promises, as shocking as Budrus or as extensive as The Settlers, but but at least it humanizes the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and helps to promote intellectual discussion.
Thoroughly thrilling, captivating, gripping and well-edited
A suspenseful, exhilarating and atmospheric crime thriller with exciting action and clever surprises.
A mesmerizing, heartbreaking, poetic, provocative and haunting experience. Patient and perceptive audiences will be rewarded the most.
Warm, darkly humorous, bittersweet and tender. Rolf Lassgård is a revelation.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Witty, fast-paced and zany with lively characters and just the right balance of action and comedy.
Cold, shallow and preposterous . It's a squandered opportunity to tell a rich, engrossing and sophisticated character-driven story for adults.
Well-acted with exquisite cinematography and has its fair share of poignant moments, but it falls short of reaching the heights of powerful coming-of-age classics like Boyhood.
Wild, whacky and wickedly funny. The best horror parody in years. It's destined to become an cult classic.
Solid performances, but the screenplay is a clunky, contrived and stilted mess.
Heartfelt, tender and relatable tapestry of love stories.
Anyone who's looking for a more profound peak behind the curtain, both intellectually and emotionally, will be left underwhelmed and disappointed.
Illuminating, poignant and even somewhat suspenseful.
Well-edited, captivating, fair and easy-to-follow, but it's ultimately not balanced enough to rise above more searing, powerful and haunting docs like Food, Inc. and Super Size Me.

Compelling and even occasionally moving regardless of where in the spectrum of pro-war vs anti-war you find yourself. Kudos to director Matthew Hausle and Steven C. Barber for introducing audiences to such a noble and extraordinary American war hero.
movie_title: Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Vital, captivating, witty and inspirational. A remarkable achievement for a first-time filmmaker!

Well-cast with dazzling visuals and production design, but somewhat dull, and it lacks enough surprises and wit to escape its mediocrity. It's lucky to have Benedict Cumberbatch who rises above the material with his charisma.
Warm, funny and enormously entertaining.
One of the most easily accessible, engaging and inspiring docs about climate change for everyone, young and old.
A genuinely moving, profound and haunting experience that might change the way you perceive the sights and sounds around you.
A lively, engaging, warts-and-all documentary.
movie_title: Vince Giordano: There's a Future in the Past (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A slick, mildy amusing and occasionally zany screwball comedy, but it's mostly witless and underwhelming while lacking risque.
Tender, warm, witty and refreshingly honest. Héctor Bonilla gives a bravura performance.
A contrived, undercooked and overstuffed drama that can't be saved by its convincingly moving performances.
A wild, riveting and illuminating roller coaster ride with twists and turns along the way
Exhausting, pretentious, and tedious. It's one of the most painfully boring, overlong and disappointing Westerns since Heaven's Gate.
Mildly entertaining with great production values, exhilarating musical numbers, and a lively supporting cast, but it lacks the heart and soul of the classic 1991 animated version.
Warm, wise, nuanced and profoundly moving.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Illuminating. A lively, mouth-watering feast for the eyes, mind and soul.
A touching father-and-son story. It's more grounded and heartfelt than Back to the Future.
An intelligent, gripping crime thriller in the vein of the great crime thrillers of the 90's like Seven and The Usual Suspects with some Hitchcockian suspense.
Equally moving, shocking and enraging.
Prepare to be enraged, riveted and profoundly moved by this searing and unflinching documentary.
Mildly entertaining with dazzling visual spectacle, but more silly, exhausting and outrageous rather than fun or funny.
movie_title: Journey to the West: The Demons Strike Back (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting, exhilarating, white-knuckle crime thriller.
A captivating, tender, and heartfelt journey well worth taking.
Breathtaking, stylish and wise. A highly immersive experience.
An intelligent, biting and quietly powerful satire.
Slick with plenty of eye candy and sporadically thrilling action scenes, but it's yet another mindless, shallow, loud, slightly tedious and overlong B-movie masquerading as an A-movie.
Michalina Olszanska's convincingly moving performance is undermined by a dull, underwhelming and shallow screenplay.
Emotionally devastating, intimate and haunting, but not insightful enough.
A mesmerizing documentary that will enlighten and captivate audiences of all ages
Well-edited, hopeful and insightful. It doesn't quite find the perfect balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually, it comes close enough.
Stylish, but insipid and increasingly asinine. Hitchcock is rolling in his grave.
A gripping, intelligent, psychological crime thriller. Prepare to be on the edge of your seat from start to finish.
An intelligent, bittersweet and wickedly funny dark comedy. It's a guilty pleasure with razor-sharp wit, bite and tenderness.
Timely! As riveting and illuminating as The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers.
A quietly gripping, slow-burning character study that's unflinching, bleak and engrossing.
Tender, poignant and refreshingly true-to-life. Riley Keough and Jena Malone give raw performances. It's more powerful than Moonlight!
Stylishly edited and timely, but it's too angry, exhausting and repetitive while failing to be inspirational, balanced or truly enlightening.
A slow-burning, intelligent suspense thriller grounded in humanism and natural performances despite an implausible, contrived third act.
Slick, gripping, provocative and enormously entertaining.
Regardless of whether or not you're a fan of Leonard Cohen's music, you'll be captivated by this behind-the-scenes documentary.
Not as scary nor as atmospheric as The Ring, but it's nonetheless creepy, suspenseful and an improvement on the sequel with great visual effects and sound design/editing.
As invigorating, illuminating, stylishly edited and captivating as Exit Through the Gift Shop.
Warm, tender and heartfelt. A funny, witty and crowd-pleasing delight! More powerful than Lion!
Prepare to be riveted by this equally enraging, terrifying and eye-opening documentary.
An exhilarating, subversive and hilarious adventure brimming with gleeful zaniness and razor-sharp wit. If you enjoyed The LEGO Movie, you'll enjoy The LEGO Batman Movie even more.
A rousing, action-packed white-knuckle thriller full of visual poetry. It's a rush of pure adrenaline.
Delightfully zany, but often silly, tedious and exhausting rather than being consistently funny.
Tender, heartfelt, well-acted and quietly powerful despite being slightly overstuffed with dramatic conflicts.
Heartbreaking and intimate, but unfocused and lacking in scope.
An equally powerful, enraging and poignant exposé of underage sex trafficking. It should be mandatory viewing for every high school student.
Dumb, shallow, stilted and more cringe-inducing than sexy. It's one of the funniest unintentional comedies of the year.
A riveting, provocative and alarming doc. Timely, potent and terrifying.
A haunting, moving, intelligent and gripping allegory. Peyton Kennedy gives a breakthrough performance.
A breezy, delightful and endearing romantic comedy. It's a perfect date movie.
A wise, tender, heartfelt and captivating journey that's well worth taking.
Visually slick and stylish, but it's not scary nor imaginative enough to escape from being mildly disappointing.
Yet another shallow, mind-numbing and overproduced Hollywood B-movie masquerading as an A-movie. It's the equivalent of watching a video game on a big screen.

A life-affirming, breathtaking, and inspirational film that will nourish your heart, mind and soul. It's the perfect antidote to Hollywood's blockbusters. Karen Allen gives the best performance of her career! What a triumph!
Charming performances by the well-cast leads, Martin Starr and Dina Shihabi, compensate for a clunky, contrived, sitcom-ish screenplay.
A very ordinary horror thriller without any shocking twists or surprises. If only the screenplay were half as clever and imaginative as the sound and visual design!
Tremendously inspirational. It's more thrilling and engrossing than Life of Pi.
One of those rare, crowd-pleasing documentaries that compels you to tap your toes and leaves you with a great big smile on your face from ear to ear upon exiting the theater.
Bold, ugly, beautiful, haunting, nauseating, pretentious, scary, tedious and disgusting. One of the most viscerally horrifying films in years. Not for the weak-stomached.
Lacks complexity, realism, wit and sophistication. Julie White radiates panache, though.
Rightfully angry, but too simplistic, annoying and tedious.
Provocative, vital and enraging. It goes further than An Inconvenient Truth.
Engaging, revealing and even a bit moving.
Entertaining and well-edited, but ultimately shallow.
A bold, outrageously funny and provocative satire. Garrone deftly blends the real with the surreal.
Unflinching, raw and bold with emotional complexity.
Contrived, corny and over-simplistic.
Brave, gritty, complex and suspenseful. Jamie Chung gives the best performance of her career.
Occasionally creepy, but mostly inert, unimaginative and tedious.
A poignant and inspirational tribute to Lieutenant Michael Patrick Murphy.
Emotionally powerful and provocative.
Underwhelming and undernourishing.
movie_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An invigorating, breathtaking and crowd-pleasing experience that feels nourishing for your mind, body and soul. It's destined to become a sleeper hit.
Equally suspenseful, moving and inspirational.
Hilarious, bizarre and provocative. You'll never look at The Shining the same way again
Riveting and vital.
Anarchic, silly, witless, cartoonish and unsophisticated despite lively performances by the talented Olesya Rulin and Joey King.
Breezy with a charming performance by Sara Rue, but too sitcomish and shallow to rise above mediocrity.
Graceful, tender and poignant with a very believable, organic character arc. It's more than your average coming-of-age story.
A bold visual feat undermined by an overstuffed, cold and shallow screenplay and awkward theatrical performances.
Irresistibly entertaining, provocative and bold.
A chilling, unnerving and psychologically horrifying experience.
movie_title: Big Foot: The Lost Coast Tapes (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A tender, warm and heartfelt drama that's grounded in humanism and well-nuanced acting. It's one of the best foreign films of the year.
A bloated, tedious, uninspired, sluggish and vapid bore that can only be enjoyed by very shallow, unctuous philistines.
Not sexy, profound or memorable despite heartfelt performances by Chris Messina and Marin Ireland. It's ultimately an exhausting and frustrating affair.
A sparkling romantic comedy brimming with razor-sharp wit and genuine poignancy. It's funnier and wiser than Knocked Up, Funny People and The 40 Year Old Virgin combined.
Clunky and lacks bite, but mostly engrossing thanks to Robert Carlyle's heartfelt, nuanced performance that adds complexity which the screenplay lacks.
Charming and sophisticated while breaking no new ground and lacking wit. The talented, sexy Adelaide Clemens radiates charisma, grace and panache.
Stylish and initially intriguing with a decent performance by Aamir Khan (and his mustache), but underwhelming, banal, tedious and lacks palpable suspense.

A shallow glimpse into the life of Heleno de Freitas that's anchored by breathtaking black-and-white cinematography and a bravura, raw performance by Rodrigo Santoro. It ultimately nourishes your heart more than your mind.
Captures the essence of modern teenage life with warmth, honesty, humor and compassion. It's equally endearing, relatable and entertaining.
Sophisticated, lyrical and quietly moving. Patient and intelligent audience members will be the most rewarded.
Heart-stopping, smart, taut and electrifying. It's one of the finest suspense thrillers in years.
Profoundly moving, unflinchingly honest and tender with brave, emotionally raw performances by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva.
Not quite a Pixar classic, but funny, witty and visually spectacular enough to be enjoyed again on the big screen.

While it's refreshing to watch a military drama that doesn't rely on action, CGI or heavy-handed preaching as a means of entertainment, Allegiance ultimately bites off more than it can chew, lacks bite and feels a little undercooked.
Most importantly it allows you to care about its very human characters and to feel their emotional pain as you watch their life unfold onscreen.
Uprising could serve as an easy-to-follow guide for American citizens on how to successfully form and implement a revolution to overthrow their government if and when it turns into a dictatorship.
Nourishes you with an interesting variety of food for thought no matter where you lie on the spectrum between pro-technology and anti-technology.
It will amuse and delight you because it never takes itself too seriously.
A breezy, thoroughly entertaining and balanced doc that sheds light on Ed Koch's panache, wisdom and sense of humor behind the curtain of politics.
Witless, lackluster and uneven despite a charismatic performance by Nicholas Hoult.
A suspenseful, intense and horrifying thriller boasting a raw performance by Neil Hopkins.
Slick, fast-paced and mindlessly entertaining despite many contrived and awkward moments. It takes a while to get used to Tyler Perry in a non-Madea role.
A warm, tender, candid and thoughtful glimpse of André Gregory behind the curtain, warts-and-all.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Highly entertaining, but not revealing or insightful enough.
An irresistibly entertaining, uplifting, well-edited tribute to the subculture of pick-up basketball in NYC.
movie_title: Doin' It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A life-affirming, emotionally captivating and rewarding experience. It treats the audience like sophisticated, mature adults---a demographic that has been sorely neglected by Hollywood nowadays.
A long, tedious, preposterous, incoherent video game made for shallow and indolent people. A lackluster blockbuster.
It doesn't offer any new or surprising information or any profound analysis, so it barely scratches the multifaceted surface of Assange and remains slightly undercooked.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally compelling and provocative character study of a brave, intelligent woman. Barbara Sukowa delivers a bravura performance.
A mindless exercise in sadism that's neither scary nor a guilty pleasure.
Banal, clunky and contrived.
A deeply moving, complex and thought-provoking parable that you won't soon forget. Martina Gedeck gives a raw, tour de force performance.
Subversive, bold and fresh. A guilty pleasure in spite of its uneven tone.
Emotionally believable performances by Vincent Lindon and Soko can't save Augustine from meandering and being tediously stuck in its 1st act.
A mildly funny, harmless comedy of errors that could have used more wit, zaniness and irreverence.
Concurrently frightening and breathtaking.
Eye-opening and enraging. Thanks to Call Me Kuchu, the legacy of David Kato, Uganda's closest equivalent to Harvey Milk, will live on.
An intelligent, riveting and terrifying thriller.
Compelling, provocative and well-edited.
Mildly suspenseful and informative, but occasionally repetitive and boring. You'll never look at a sommelier the same way again.
This is music to the ears of everyone who values democracy, evolution and critical thinking.
movie_title: Creating Freedom: The Lottery of Birth (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A long, boring video game that's more dumb than fun.

Warm and poignant, but with excessive use of concert footage and lack of insight/intrigue. Strictly for avid fans of Kate McGarrigle. Just listening to the soundtrack might be more rewarding and satisfying.
movie_title: Sing Me the Songs That Say I Love You: A Concert for Kate McGarrigle (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Equally riveting, moving and delightful. It will make you stand up and cheer.
Warm, poignant and family-friendly with a rushed, contrived ending.
Inspirational. It finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally and intellectually.
Initially engaging, but increasingly tedious and boring. Strictly for opera aficionados.
Initially funny and imaginative, but increasingly lazy, unfunny and tedious. It would have worked better as a short.
An intelligent, slow-burn political thriller boasting stellar performances from its talented ensemble cast that compensate for the screenplay's minor shortcomings.
Gentle, sweet and understated. A beautiful, quietly moving drama.
An uneven, underwritten amalgam of comedy, drama and suspense that fails to pack a comedic, emotional or intellectual punch.
Captivating, heartfelt and gripping. It should be a requirement for every young American to watch this documentary.
Too simplistic. You can't help but recall a much more insightful and thorough doc that treads similar ground,  Food, Inc.
Weird, funny, thought-provoking and suspenseful. The ultimate midnight movie. You've never seen anything like it before.
Warm, delightful and poignant. You'll never look at a garbage collector the same way again.
Emotionally and intellectually demanding, but occasionally exhausting and tedious.
Emotionally resonating. Assayas has a keen eye for period detail and atmosphere.
Leaves you undernourished both intellectually and emotionally.
Solid performances can't save the film from its banal, convoluted screenplay that leaves no room for interpretation or subtlety.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Shallow, tedious and, worst of all, boring.
A well-edited doc with its heart in the right place, but it's incomplete, simplistic and euphemistic.
Fascinating. Equally entertaining and informative.
Fun and amusing albeit a little too much navel-gazing and low on insight.

Stellar performances and visual pizazz, but suffers from emotional hollowness and excessive style over substance. Combining rap and hip hop music with The Great Gatsby is like mixing ketchup with caviar. F. Scott Fitzgerald is rolling in his grave.
A very poignant doc that celebrates the genuine virtues of compassion, friendship.
Among those rare, delightful music documentaries, in the vein of Standing in the Shadows of Motown, that provokes you emotionally and intellectually while remaining entertaining throughout.
A mildly engaging introduction to Krishna Das.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An inspiration for current convicts and as a cautionary tale for everyone else who may get tempted to go down the path of drugs and violence.
Suspenseful, unpredictable, mature, tender and funny. A triumph.
A vital, heartbreaking and informative history lesson as well as a cautionary tale.
movie_title: Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City - 1900-1922 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Close Encounters of the Third Kind meets The Blair Witch Project. Hair-raising, chilling and riveting. It will scare the living daylights out of you.
Bizarre, perverse, funny, magical, exhilarating, creepy, beautiful, mesmerizing and slightly exhausting with a tour de force performance by Denis Lavant.
Taut, intelligent, funny, timely and thoroughly entertaining. Finally, there comes along a Hollywood movie made for adults.
An amusing, well-shot deadpan comedy that pokes subversive fun at the American Western genre, but it eventually loses comedic steam.
The first smart, sexy and sophisticated romantic comedy since 500 Days of Summer. Finally, a romcom for adults!
Underwhelming, bland and pedestrian with a weak screenplay that squanders its many opportunities to be thrilling, provocative and poignant.
A richly textured and human drama brimming with warmth, tenderness and pure, unadulterated poignancy.
An underwhelming experience despite stylish cinematography and a brave performance by Rachel Weisz.
Often fascinating and provocative.
A delightfully refreshing comedy that eventually runs out of steam.
Sweet, funny and uplifting. Shu Qi sizzles.
Well-edited and mildly engaging, but it barely scratches the surface of its subject matter.
Unpredictable, intriguing and unflinching, but somewhat uneven, heavy-handed and fails to pack a strong sociopolitical punch.
A riveting docu-thriller that will wake you up and shake you up to the inexcusable failures of the American justice system. You will never look at an interrogation the same way again.
A well-acted, intelligent and riveting thrill ride that will take your breath away. It's one of the most powerful gangster films in years.
Gritty, riveting and well-acted.
Yet another brainless, overbloated and mostly underwhelming blockbuster despite marvelous visual effects.
Unflinchingly honest and emotionally devastating.
Suspenseful, intriguing, wise and genuinely heartfelt.
Bold, shameless and outrageously funny. You'll laugh your head off.
Often feels like life itself: indescribable, complex, wondrous and beautiful.
A somber, heart-wrenching drama as well as a very timely critique of modern society.
A long, vapid and tedious orgasm of CGI effects that will leave you exacerbated.
Overlong and occasionally limp, but it will make you laugh more often than not.
The experience of watching this delightful film is like sipping a refreshing glass of lemonade (spiked with a hint of booze) on a hot summer day.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A brave, provocative, thoroughly compelling feat. You won't forget it anytime soon.
Captivating, provocative and stylishly-edited. While An Inconvenient Truth invoked a lot of fear about global warming, here comes An Inconsistent Truth to calm you down and to open your eyes.
An exhilarating, thrilling and thoroughly suspenseful action thriller.
A riveting, gritty, palpably entertaining drama.
An invigorating, charming, witty and crowd-pleasing delight that's destined to become a classic while skyrocketing the careers of Jean Dujardin and Bérénice Béjo.
Wondrous, captivating and genuinely heartfelt.
movie_title: In Heaven Underground: The Weissensee Jewish Cemetery (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sans sufficient insight, it feels incomplete and a tad underwhelming, but quite heartfelt and mildly engaging nonetheless.
Rivals Gigli as one of the most cringe-inducing, asinine and silly romcoms in quite some time. Save yourself the torture and just rent Love Actually instead.
Charming, harmless, refreshingly bizarre and unabashedly silly, but kids will be much more entertained than adults.
An often exhilarating, lively, magical and breathtaking experience of Pina Bausch's art.
Atmospheric, but underwhelming, underwritten and emotionally hollow.
Well-shot and edited, but low on provocative insight.
Powerful, illuminating and inspirational.
movie_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully awkward, melodramatic and contrived. Skip the movie and just buy its uplifting soundtrack.
Titillating and captivating, but low on insight and occasionally tedious.
Exhilarating, intelligent and compelling with plenty of surprises and dazzling animation.
movie_title: Fullmetal Alchemist: The Sacred Star of Milos (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Well-acted and mildly engaging, but too much melodrama and not enough compelling insight.
A thoroughly exhilarating, imaginative and character driven sci-fi thriller that's invigoratingly smart and surprisingly poignant. It's destined to become a sci-fi classic.
A quietly devastating, powerful and poignant drama boasting an unflinchingly honest and well-nuanced performance by Linda Cardellini.
Stylish, exhilarating action sequences compensate for the corny drama and occasional tedium.
Alien Outpost pales in comparison to District 9. It probably would have worked better as a short.
Captivating, engrossing and enraging.
movie_title: The Pruitt-igoe Myth: An Urban History (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Inspirational and uplifting. It will make you stand up and cheer.
movie_title: Bonsai People: The Vision of Muhammad Yunus (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The funniest comedy in years, and the most touching story of genuine friendship since The Shawshank Redemption. Only a cynic would be able to resist its charms, humor, and humanity.
A mildly engaging multi-layered story with very fine, heartfelt performances undermined by a banal screenplay and clunky directing.
Suspenseful, wickedly funny and clever, Headhunters offers more bang for your buck than most modern crime thrillers.
Surprisingly funny, smart and, dare I say, tender. The first great blockbuster of the summer.
Rarely has a romantic drama been made with such genuine, pure, unadulterated emotion. Emilia Zoryan delivers a radiant, well-nuanced performance.
Hilarious, bold, honest and witty. Meryl Streep sizzles. One of the smartest romantic comedies in years. It will go down as a classic.
Preposterous, inane and silly, but outrageously funny.
Amusing and even liberating to watch, but lacks sufficient insight and revelations. How often do you get to see a doc about elderly prostitutes?
Highly entertaining, eye-opening, scary and enraging. You'll never look at Obama the same way ever again nor will you trust his empty promises.

A strong, moving performance by Rebecca Hall coupled with an eerie atmosphere thanks to the top-notch cinematography provides enough palpable tension and scares to compensate for its weak, convoluted ending.
Well-acted and initially refreshing, but uneven, unfocused and too long.
Lackluster, inane and witless with too many jokes that fall flat.
Initially diverting and thrilling, but with diminishing returns. It's excessively inane and cartoonish. Not enough pleasure to call it a guilty pleasure.
A vital, informative wake-up call that will make you feel equally enraged and inspired.
After a promising first hour filled with suspense and clever dark comedy, it sinks into implausibility, silliness and banality. Its bite could use sharper teeth.
Sporadically intriguing and poignant, yet meandering and incomplete. It caters more to the heart than to the mind.
A stylishly-directed, intelligent and well-acted murder mystery brimming with thrills, suspense and intrigue. It deserves an American remake.
Wise, warm, sexy and sophisticated with tender, well-nuanced performances by John Shea and Lea Thompson.
Heartwarming, perceptive and funny. Elizabeth Olsen sizzles.
Mildly engaging, but leaves you hungry for more emotional and intellectual depth.
Trite, banal and underwhelming.
Emotionally cathartic and engrossing with just the right amount of levity.
Poignant, funny and well-acted. A commendable directorial debut of Matthew Lillard.
Bold, wickedly funny and quietly suspenseful. An outrageously entertaining, smartly-directed guilty pleasure with exquisite production values.
Banal, contrived and stilted with a made-for-TV movie feel.
A sexy, smart and sophisticated exploration of sex, love and everything in between.
Honest, illuminating and compassionate. An extraordinary documentary.
movie_title: Deconstructing Dad: The Music, Machines and Mystery of Raymond Scott (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Smartly-written, riveting and profoundly human with Oscar-caliber performances. It's the most emotionally and intellectually rewarding blockbuster in years, and thus far the best American film of 2012.
An epic, dazzling and thrilling adventure for all ages.
Bold, witty and hilarious. A slice of comedy heaven. You'll laugh until it hurts.
Beautifully-shot, but undercooked and too heavy on metaphors. Josh Lucas elevates the film with a strong, well-nuanced performance.
An illuminating, provocative documentary that will leave you enraged, and rightfully so.
Well-acted, deeply human and emotionally resonating.
Sad, poignant, funny and, above all, painfully honest.
Spectacular, thrilling and heartfelt. The best war film since Saving Private Ryan.
A wildly entertaining and provocative about a bold, honest and charismatic artist.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Tasteless, witless and mean-spirited. A painfully unfunny debacle.
Powerful, provocative and deeply moving. One of the most vital and enraging documentaries of the year.
Great CGI animation doesn't compensate for forgettable characters, an uneven tone, and a banal story that fails to pack enough of a comedic, imaginative and emotional punch.
A somber, melancholic drama with emotionally raw performances by its non-professional actors.

It's like watching a cleverly subversive, inspired and hilarious opening act followed by a very weak, uninspired, and repetitious main act. If you've seen the trailer, you've seen most of the funny scenes already.
Too long and dramatically flaccid. It's well-shot and initially compelling, but ultimately suffers from style over substance.
Underwhelming and, worst of all, boring.
Enraging, but often heavy-handed and speculative.

The rare guilty pleasure that offers both style and substance along with dark comedy, suspense, tongue-in-cheek humor and Benicio Del Toro who's just as scene-chewing as Javier Bardem was in No Country for Old Men.
A quietly suspenseful, provocative and surprising directorial debut. It shows great promise in Martin Donovan's budding career as a writer/director.
Undercooked, lazy and frustratingly underwhelming despite solid performances.
The American movie industry desperately needs a clever mystery thriller, but the sophomoric, nauseating and increasingly preposterous Red Lights fails to rise to that call.
Sexy, refreshing, well-acted and consistently compelling. It offers much more to offer than just beautiful set and costume design.
Equally poignant and riveting. One of the best mystery thrillers since Tell No One .

Impressive CGI, but loud, long, inane and bland with many plot holes and tedious action sequences that are more exhausting and underwhelming than exhilarating. It fails to display the brilliance of filmmaker Guillermo del Toro.
A mildly engaging introduction to the architectural work of Norman Foster, but it barely scratches the surface.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Refreshingly weird, drolly satirical and provocative. Its style becomes part of its substance.
A delightful, breezy and outrageously funny slice of mindless entertainment with a charming cast.
Equally provocative and captivating. It has more imagination and intelligence than all of the Hollywood films in recent memory combined.
Moderately captivating, complex and sophisticated with exquisite production values, but too much exposition diminishes the dramatic momentum.
Contrived and somewhat dull, but the talented Daniel Brühl's performance provides much-needed genuine poignancy and charisma.
Warm and heartfelt, but tedious, overlong and intellectually underwhelming.
An equally heartbreaking and enraging exposé about an important human rights issue.
It will nourish your mind, body and soul, and inspire you to embark on your own pilgrimage at some point in your life.
movie_title: Walking The Camino: Six Ways To Santiago (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Repetitive, juvenile and asinine. Yet another example of the decay of American comedy.
Complex, suspenseful, unpredictable and increasingly profound. One of those rare sci-fi movies with a brain. You'll want to see it again.
Moving, charming, warm and wise.
Wise, honest, breezy, witty and profound, A Summer's Tale is an intellectually and emotionally rewarding date movie for sophisticated couples.
The first great American film this year that can't be turned into a video game. It deserves to become a sleeper hit, and has a well-balanced blend of commercial and art-house qualities.
Provocative, refreshing, well-organized and well-researched. It will spark many debates about America's past, present and future.
movie_title: America: Imagine the World Without Her (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A heartfelt tribute to one of the most famous and significant film critics of all time.

Genuinely poignant, profound and relatable with a strong beginning, middle and end. Why can't Hollywood make films like this anymore? Now critics need only worry about their other 9 Best Films of the Year.
f there were double features nowadays, The DescentBeneath be the underwhelming B movie.

An intelligent slow-burn thriller. Philip Seymour Hoffman knocks it out of the ballpark. Your patience will be rewarded. It wouldn't be surprising if he were nominated later this year for a posthumous Best Actor award.
An engaging character study that effectively skirts the fine line between comedy and tragedy, but the ending feels rather glib.
Heartbreaking, illuminating, frightening and intimate. Bravo to the filmmakers for shedding light on an issue that many people can relate to to some degree.
Amusing, but low on laughs, irreverence and bite despite a talented cast and a kookie premise.

A potent, frightening and poignant reminder of how easy it is to lose democracy in modern day America. If this were 1930s Germany, DOJ prosecutors Carmen Ortiz and Stephen Heymann would probably work for Adolf Hitler.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Charming and amusing albeit ultimately underwhelming without enough meat on its bones.
The well-nuanced performance of Robert Duvall, among the greatest actors of our time, compensates for the contrived and oversimplified screenplay.
A less preachy Religulous, but just as outrageously entertaining.
Hank and Asha might be the best modern love story since Once or Before Sunset. It's the rare love story that has both style and substance.
A suspense thriller grounded in social realism. It's yet another example of how the most effective suspense thrillers are usually found outside of Hollywood and with much lower budgets.
Genuinely scary and suspenseful because it leaves room for imagination and doesn't rely on gore or use a "found footage" device.
Heartfelt and provocative, but not thorough or well-rounded enough.
Bold, provocative, unflinching and surprisingly funny.
Well-edited and refreshingly character-driven with a decent performance by Tom Sizemore, but somewhat contrived and lacking in depth.
A warm, inspirational and unflinchingly honest doc that's equally moving and uplifting.
Breathtaking scenery and slick editing, but convoluted, unfocused and overlong.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A ho-hum B-movie with an A-list cast. Besides the solid performances, it offers nothing else to hold your interest.
The family-friendly Road to the Open is the kind of film that Hollywood rarely makes anymore: character-driven, warm, charming, human, genuinely uplifting and inspirational.
Breathtaking, unusual and transcendent. Patient viewers will be rewarded.
Powerful, wise and uplifting. It's a perfect Father's Day movie. One of the best family dramas in years.
If Desert Riders doesn't make you enraged and move you to tears, you must be made out of stone.
A leisurely-paced, operative love story with well-nuanced performances. If there were any justice, it would be nominated for Best Costume Design, Best Set Design and Best Cinematography.
Well-balanced, witty and illuminating. A must-see for anyone who's even remotely interested in photography
Insightful, but strictly for avid fans of classical chamber music.
movie_title: Speak The Music: Robert Mann And The Mysteries Of Chamber Music (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Bold, imaginative and visually stylish.
