Viscerally thrilling and intense. If you're looking for a summer blockbuster that delivers pure escapism for 2 hours without overstaying its welcome, it won't disappoint you.
Genuinely heartwarming, uplifting and wholesome. It's a pleasantly diverting antidote to the many loud, shallow and action-packed summer blockbusters. An ideal sports drama for the entire family.
Quietly powerful, haunting, unflinchingly honest and character-driven.
Moving and humanizing. It will forever change the way you look at nurses.
Tender, understated, deeply human and quietly powerful. John Lithgow and Alfred Molina give career-best performances.
A refreshing, genuinely heartfelt coming-of-age story.
Breathtaking scenery and interesting choices of music, but too aimless and formless. You can't help but wonder what Werner Herzog would've done with it.
movie_title: The Expedition to the End of the World (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, eye-opening and enraging exposé albeit its talking heads approach is somewhat dry. Dr. Ralph Moss makes for a very interesting subject.
Filled with heartbreaking moments and unflinching humanity while shedding light on an important human rights issue.
Equally thrilling, inspirational and poignant.
A smart, refreshingly whimsical and witty political satire that boasts winning performances by Toni Servillo in dual roles. It might as well be called Politics Italian-Style.
Stunning, informative and captivating. You'll have a much deeper understanding of and passion for pelicans.
One of the most essential, potent and haunting documentary war films ever made.
Genuinely warmhearted, wise, funny and relatable.
Warm, tender and heartfelt. It's a profound, honest and poignant drama brimming with well-nuanced performances. Refreshingly un-Hollywood!
Fair, balanced, humanizing and profoundly moving
A genuinely heartfelt portrait of Haitian life in 1980s Brooklyn brimming with humanism and emotionally resonant performances.
Illuminating, but too dry and exhausting.
Well-acted, beautifully shot, and sporadically provocative, but dramatically inert and ultimately underwhelming.
A cringe-worthy, stilted, awkward and bloated mess.
movie_title: Life Of An Actress The Musical (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A toothless, brainless comedic misfire that's low on laughs, wit and clever satire. If you're expecting this to become a cult classic comedy, you'll be sorely disappointed.
Haunting, emotionally devastating, thought-provoking and deeply human despite that it's overlong and very slow-paced.
Breezy, harmless, mildly amusing and uplifting with a charismatic ensemble cast.
Surprisingly insightful, suspenseful and amusing. You'll never look at General Tso's Chicken the same way again.
Witty, charming and warm with a fine balance between drama and comedy. It's equally wise, funny and tender.
Gritty, intense, unflinching and taut. An emotional punch to the gut. Jack O'Connell delivers a bravura, star-making performance. It's the best prison drama since A Prophet.
A suspenseful, surprising and intriguing emotional journey.
A sparkling, heartfelt albeit slightly uneven dramedy refreshingly grounded in realism.
A lyrical, excessively talky, initially fascinating drama that lacks nuance and complexity, and eventually overstays its welcome.
A profoundly moving, suspenseful and inspirational journey!
Lean, gritty and filled with visual pizzazz. It's refreshing to see someone other than Liam Neeson in a revenge thriller. Keanu Reeves is in top form!

Calm, yet enraging. Among the most frightening and important films of the year. It must be seen by all Americans for the sake of democracy. Every U.S. government official should undergo a mandatory mental health evaluation!
Provocative and mildly engaging. It could have used a better organization of its wealth of facts.
movie_title: Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unpredictable, atmospheric and enigmatic. This isn't your average coming-of-age film which makes it all the more refreshing, unique and un-Hollywood.
Thoroughly captivating, thrilling and inspirational. It demands to be seen on the big screen.
Amusing, much like its title, but often shallow and incomplete.
Harmless, breezy and mildly entertaining. Kids will love it.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Well-edited, provocative and thrilling. It would make a great double feature with Hearts and Minds.
Mysterious, suspenseful, engrossing and foreboding. Sally Kirkland gives an unflinchingly raw, tender performance.
Timely, taut, spellbinding and surprisingly heartwarming. It might be the most important documentary about Israeli-Palestinian relations since Promises.
Persuasive and frightening. It's much more illuminating and thorough than Michael Moore's Capitalism: A Love Story.
Bold, darkly comic, refreshingly honest and self-deprecating.
Vital! Powerful! Illuminating! Eye-opening! It will change the way you look at fuel forever.
Thoroughly compelling and fascinating with a brilliantly mad, enigmatic subject.
Refreshingly un-Hollywood and understated. It brims with genuine warmth, tenderness and humanity. A real triumph.
Effectively creepy, foreboding and much smarter than most modern horror remakes. It should be seen on the big screen.
movie_title: Más Negro Qué La Noche (Darker than Night) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Suspenseful and compelling with great camera work and fine performances by Joan Allen and Anthony LaPaglia, despite an ending that feels rushed and contrived.
An intense, emotionally-charged and captivating triumph brimming with powerhouse performances by Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons. They both deserve an Oscar nomination.
Well-researched, potent and equally informative, emotionally devastating and exhausting.
An uneven, heavy-handed blend of darkly comic satire, drama and magical realism saved by strong performances and an ambiguous ending that leaves enough room for interpretation.
A mesmerizing, tense and deeply human battle of the mind and heart with note-perfect performances by Niels Arestrup and André Dussollier.
Exhilarating, wise and genuinely heartfelt. It's perfect entertainment for the whole family! It will make you stand up and cheer!
Groundbreaking, fair and balanced. It's the kind of powerful, intelligent and compelling documentary you'll be talking about for weeks!
Just as exciting and intriguing as a Bond film. Pierce Brosnan is at his best.
Spellbinding, intelligent and suspenseful. Jessica Lange, one of the greatest actresses of our time, delivers a mesmerizing, magnificent performance.
Its creepy setting, lighting and sound designs deliver some scares, but there's not enough in terms of surprises or cleverness.
Creepy, gradually suspenseful and well-acted, but not as provocative or profound as it could have been.
Irreverent, campy and zany. A guilty pleasure.
Not nearly as moving, crowd-pleasing or powerful as Searching for Sugar Man or Standing in the Shadows of Motown, but it's nonetheless an insightful, slick and engaging music doc for fans of hip-hop.
Fascinating and deeply moving. Brings out Hawking's humility, warmth and wit. The best doc about Stephen Hawking ever made.
Witless and asinine. Not nearly as funny as The Hebrew Hammer.
No matter which side of the abortion issue you're on, prepare to be emotionally devastated.
Suspenseful, well-edited and adequately illuminating without being too heavy or dry
Slightly oversimplified, but it's equally inspiring and moving nonetheless.
Captivating, uplifting and even somewhat engrossing
We Are What We Are will satiate your hunger for palpable suspense, horror and intrigue. It's one of most effectively terrifying remakes in years.
Enlightening and philosophical.
Refreshingly stylish and enigmatic. It brings out Harry Dean Stanton's warmth, humility and sense of humor.
Riveting and transfixing. Most likely the closest you'll ever come to meeting a shepherd and grasping what it's like to be one.
A viscerally exhilarating 91-minute thrill ride. It won't be remembered for its dialogue or characters, just for its game-changing sound and visual effects. Its style becomes its substance.
My Last Day Without You has the true kind of special effects that many Hollywood films lack these days: warmth, depth and a soul.
A sweeping love story. Engaging, uplifting and genuinely heartfelt.
Extensive, thorough and illuminating. It finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually.
A somewhat tedious slow-burn drama with waning tension, but saved by very raw, natural performances. It's quite refreshing to watch a cabin-in-the-woods story with no one getting killed.
Surprising, clever and twisted with a convincingly sweet and creepy performance by Christopher Denham.
Slickly edited and initially intriguing, but it lacks something that's a requirement for the vast majority of documentaries: revealing insights about its subject matter.
Illuminating, intimate and witty.
movie_title: Gahan Wilson: Born Dead, Still Weird (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Eye-opening, compelling and accessible to the laymen.
Refreshingly intelligent, subversive and psychologically terrifying. It's much more than your average zombie film.
Mesmerizing and heartbreaking with a brave, raw and convincingly moving performance by Juliette Binoche.
A powerful wake-up call. It will make your blood boil.
Heartbreaking and profound. You'll be balling your eyes out, unless you're made of stone.
A wise, heartwarming, uplifting and inspiring coming-of-age film for the entire family. You'll laugh, you'll cry. It's one of the best films of year.
Prepare to be shocked, disgusted, enraged and emotionally devastated. It's the most terrifying film in years.
Solid performances by its talented cast barely compensate for the lack of depth in the toothless, overly simplistic screenplay.
Riveting, alarming, heartbreaking and well-edited. You'll never look at an orca or SeaWorld the same way again.
Equally heartbreaking, informative and heartwarming. Unless you're made of stone, you will not be dry eyed by the time the end credits roll. It's easily accessible for all ages.
The funniest, smartest American comedy in years. It's destined to become a cult classic.
An outrageous, bizarre screwball comedy that offers plenty of irreverent, anarchic fun. A mindlessly entertaining B-movie.
movie_title: Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A stylish, bold and bleak sociocultural commentary. Effectively cold, sad, empty and unpleasant, just like its characters.

Disturbing and enraging. It raises awareness about the searing topic of invasion of privacy in an entertaining, easy-to-follow fashion that includes comic relief and doesn't resort to merely one talking head after another.

Yet another shallow, dumb blockbuster that could easily be turned into a video game. Matt Damon and Jodie Foster are both underserved by the weak script that favors mind-numbing CGI and action over character development and intelligence.
Contemplative, well-balanced and fascinating. You'll find it to be provocative no matter what your religion is.
A gentle, informative elegy for Coney Island which will never be the same again.
movie_title: ZIPPER: Coney Island's Last Wild Ride (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A provocative, illuminating and vital tribute to Herbert Block. It should be mandatory viewing for every young American.
Equally heartbreaking and heartwarming. It's one of the best love stories in years.
Understated, psychologically disturbing and complex with haunting images.
Strong performances and exquisite, breathtaking cinematography barely compensate for a pedestrian, underwhelming screenplay.
Refreshingly intelligent and palpably suspenseful. Josh Duhamel and Dan Fogler give the best performance of their career.
An emotionally resonating, gripping and vital account from a Holocaust survivor.
Insightful, surprising and amusing.
Solid performances can't save the undercooked, shallow, overly simplistic screenplay.
Equally inspirational and moving.

The kind of film that Hollywood rarely makes anymore: smart, deep, honest, genuinely poignant and complex. It will nourish your heart, mind and soul. Shanola Hampton delivers a bravura, star-making performance.
Palpably suspenseful, engrossing, bold and intelligent. It's a new American classic that will be remembered for many years to come. Robert Redford delivers a tour de force performance.
A delightfully weird, invigorating and brilliant slice of indie cinema heaven. It's destined to become a cult classic.
Repetitive, overlong and, worst of all, not illuminating enough.
Well-acted, captivating, nuanced and emotionally resonating. Not a single moment rings false. One the best films of the year.

Unsophisticated and cartoonish, but well-cast and kid-friendly in an old-fashioned way.

movie_review_blurb: Uplifting, engrossing and thrilling while remaining accessible to both art-house and mainstream audiences. It's destined to become a sleeper hit.
A genuinely poignant, compelling and well-acted family drama.

Stilted and lackluster despite impeccable production design and intense war scenes.
An ambitious, visually stunning achievement. Mesmerizing and transfixing, but eventually becomes tedious and repetitive.
Elliptical, lyrical and provocative film and filled with visual poetry. It defies genre while remaining unpredictable and refreshingly un-Hollywood.
A tender, heartfelt and understated coming-of-age story that becomes slightly uneven when introducing thriller elements.
A genuinely heartfelt, adequately informative introduction to the life and music of Mercedes Sosa.

movie_review_blurb: Warm, wise, sophisticated and deeply human. Paulina García is a revelation. It's the kind of film that will linger in your mind for weeks.
Outrageous, unintentionally funny, cartoonish, dumb and consistently entertaining---in other words: the ultimate B-movie that's best watched at midnight with a group of friends while intoxicated.

Shallow, contrived, toothless and ultimately forgettable.
Well-edited and often thrilling, but leaves you with more questions than answers and feels incomplete.

Illuminating, profound and poignant.

An eye-opening, searing, powerful and persuasive exposé. You'll be enraged, shocked and intellectually provoked. It's a must-see for every American, young and old.

The scenery throughout is elemental in force: sparking lava, lapping waves, volcanic dust and gnarled kava roots create an almost mythical atmosphere.
It's just another thoughtless cash-grab sequel in a horror-movie franchise better off dead.
All those years in the oven, and "The Comedian" still comes out half-baked.

Diesel is ridiculous here: a puffy, lunk-headed James Bond pushing 50, garbling witless wisecracks through what sounds like a mouthful of Pop Rocks in the rare screen time he can grab from his obvious stunt doubles.
The visuals are up for the challenge in this fantastical meditation on childhood grief. The writing, however, is not.
Executed with love and peopled with actors who breathe life into their characters ... "Hidden Figures" is precisely the delight it aims to be.
Why watch "Why Him?"
This is all very dumb. That the film doesn't know it is agony.
"Evolution" is a work daring in its singular vision and refusal to compromise with viewers.

With the exception of light narration by Daisy Ridley - a nice detail, casting the female Jedi in a film very much about girl power - Bell lets the action onscreen tell a story that's every bit as rousing as a Disney adventure.
The film has the CliffsNotes attributes of "Catcher in the Rye" - angst, loneliness, rebellion - but little of the life force or character depth that has made readers identify with them for decades.
A merely genial comedy that aims for baseline competence, and no higher.
Burton reins in his worst impulses, bad habits that he's been cultivating for over a decade, to make a wickedly dark children's movie that is, finally, blessedly, fun to look at.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a slight film, but one that hits all the tricky emotional and comedic notes without a hint of cruelty.
This is a kid's film for hire, with none of the creativity, emotion and design that elevate the genre to art, or even simply a fun time at the movies.

For all of Cianfrance's seriousness, the material proves too essentially melodramatic, hokey and self-serious to save. No gorgeous cinematography and no cast, no matter how A-list, can ultimately save this material from itself.

The real power of "Beatriz at Dinner" is that it isn't about politics but the human heart. Beatriz and Strutt are not arguing legislation; they're arguing two visions of the American dream, two visions of the human soul.
Lazy gags, and it's been done better elsewhere.
To Nesher's credit, "Past Life" never feels exploitative - a chief danger in mining the Holocaust for drama. But it also never fully coheres.
This foul-mouthed medieval romp is occasionally hilarious and frequently improper - though a little more scripting and a little less romping would have served it well.
"A Fantastic Woman" is a superb Chilean drama, at times infuriating but never despairing.
For anyone familiar with the original "Peter Rabbit," it's a little depressing to see its storybook charm reduced to slapstick.
It's a Frankenstein's monster of teen comedies, lumbering from one cliché to the next on its way to an inevitable conclusion.
Haneke's technique is almost provocation, and it proves a fascinating intellectual exercise. But while you can admire the construction, you can't live in it.
The title "Acts of Violence" has less to do with the storyline of the movie it graces and more about what's perpetrated against the audience watching it.
There are slapstick hijinks and silly scenarios aplenty, but at its heart "Paddington 2" has something serious to say about making the world a better place through daily acts of kindness.
The dialogue is agony. Winslet is given some especial doozies to deliver with a straight face.
"Thelma" treads the line between the psychological and supernatural, gracefully at first, and then with increasing abandon.
The animation is expressive, as lush and detailed as tapestry. Harsh landscapes shimmer with beauty, even when littered with the bones of landmines and abandoned tanks.
A morbidly fascinating peek behind the blood-stained curtains.
IIt's kind of funny the first time a cute kid drops an F-bomb out of the blue; the fourth time, less so.
"The Snowman" is like if aliens studied humanity and tried to make their own movie in an attempt to communicate with us.
"Goodbye Christopher Robin" is an emotionally layered story about failures in parenting that gave rise to one of our most enduring joys.
It's always nice when a kid's film aims higher than the bare necessities, especially when it's a beloved property that doesn't have to.
There's daring in the film's slow unfurling. The problem, though, isn't one of patience but of payoff. "Woodshock" is beautiful but it's all chassis, a root-dead tree that crumbles beneath the ax.

A collective of narrative and stylistic cliches, "Rebel in the Rye" is lousy with hagiography, stripping Salinger of any danger, allure or mystery, and making him instead just another insufferable poet-philosopher in your MFA class.
"Crown Heights" is soul-shaking only in the abstract. In execution, it's deathly dull.
Cliches, cheap laughs, narrative short cuts and budget animation undermine an otherwise sweet tale of self-empowerment that should have stuck the landing.
Aside from a handful of chuckles and high-octane action sequences, "The Hitman's Bodyguard" is an ugly film lacking a moral center.
While a bit ponderous and overlong, it is a heartfelt appreciation of ordinary people turned heroes in extraordinary circumstances.
It's mature enough to grasp that family is complex, and the existence of abuse and neglect does not negate the existence of love.
"City of Ghosts" isn't merely about the personal sacrifices of these men, but a testament to the necessity of a free and open press the world over.
You don't cast Charlize Theron to lay waste to scores of German and Russian operatives in a Cold War-era spy thriller unless you intend to have her do it in style.
Shot with unsparing coldness, "Lady Macbeth" is a disturbing character study and dark moral meditation. And like the blood on its namesake's hands, it's not easily washed out.
At its best, it hits the gut with the free-fall feel of a theme-park ride. But it's a long and winding path back to the gate, and "Valerian" loses its way many times, however beautifully.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Can we collectively agree to put a moratorium on the stoner comedy? Or at least hand out a limited number of vouchers to filmmakers per decade?

There's a limit to how much patience one has for spending time with terrible people living large. But for all the lackluster familiarity of the film's style, the story is too interesting, too baffling to deny.
First-time filmmaker Richard Tanne eschews politics and heavy foreshadowing, opting instead to craft a breezy, intimate and tender film about two people making that fateful first connection.
It may not be something we've never seen before, but it's something we can benefit from seeing again.
The strength of "Peace Officer" is that it doesn't attempt to pit the viewer against the police.
[A] charming, if completely obvious, documentary.

Though polished and image-conscious, offering too little insight into the physical and psychological trauma suffered in the bullet's wake, the film is nevertheless moving without resorting to saccharine overtures.

Oyelowo and Mara try to bring humanity and tension to the testimonial thriller of two lost souls finding their way together, but they only succeed in bursts, hampered by marketing copy masquerading as dialogue.
Without a buttress of cleverness, "Cooties" is mere freewheeling idiocy.
Whether it's the expanse of rolling hills and frozen lakes or close-ups of a baby wolf's soft fur, the camera hugs each texture with awe.
Over-simplified with a lot of emotional hand-holding, but just charismatic enough to work.
"American Ultra" is doodles in a math-class notebook given a budget, and although it's frequently as stupid as it sounds, it's amiable enough to pass the bowl around.
It would be unbearable if it weren't so completely self-aware.
Heller's debut directorial effort is incisive and universal, despite its very specific and detailed setting.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a confident thriller suffused with dread that builds suspense without breaking until it's too late to turn back - with a few jump scares thrown in for good measure.
Inexpert execution, lazy attention to detail and a lackluster lead performance conspire to render a juicy mystery rather boring.
It's the same warmth and kindness that makes us care about these two characters that smothers the film's fire before it can ever get roaring.
"Southpaw" is all about the fist. There's no delicate footwork here, no lingering grace notes. It's a film played entirely in power chords.
It's got a story every bit as bold and fearless as its approach - the kind of primal story that's beyond the ken of language.
To the film's credit, it knows it's ridiculous. It's aiming for ridiculous, and it hits the mark as precisely as the strippers groove half-naked to their beats.
It's the Walmart of feel-good family films: accessible, cheaply made, useful in a pinch and full of American flags.
"Madame Bovary's" attempt to give Flaubert's text the benefit of a 21st-century feminist perspective is admirable if unsuccessful.
The tired caper flick can't crack a smile, never mind a bank vault.
There is nothing brave about "Bravetown," a film so paint-by-the-numbers bland that its efforts to piggyback the sacrifice of American servicemen and women for emotional depth is downright craven.

The film goes off the beaten path to tell a very familiar story in an unfamiliar way, turning the mismatched buddy dynamic Black and Marsden had developed into something much more complicated and interesting.
The whole range of human emotion - love, lust, anger, jealousy, despair, grief - is felt through Plympton's animation. It's just a shame that his boundless creativity doesn't extend to the narrative.

Although its chief asset is its inherently entertaining subject matter, "Monkey Kingdom" does far more than just let the cameras roll: It teases a compelling drama out of one monkey tribe's complicated social hierarchy ...

Although it's enjoyable, actor Chris Messina's directorial debut is somehow less than the sum of its parts, wading only through the shallow end of familiar human conflicts resolved too conveniently to satisfy.

It's exactly what you'd expect, except executed with more-than-typical competence with the help of a few excellent actors and some gorgeously photographed rodeo scenes that capture the drama and thrill of bull riding.

Under a less masterful hand, you'd be dying for a fistfight, a sex scene or a gunshot to shatter the calm. But Koreeda makes thrilling the rich inner lives of four young women trying to navigate rocky emotional terrain in the wake of their father's death.
Suffragette, like Maud, is modest in scope and ambition, and is more emotionally affecting for it.
Despite its sparseness and haunting photography, the film proves to be little more than a home-invasion thriller low on thrills.
An affecting drama that is honest and clear-eyed about Hirut's trauma, and the ongoing struggles she'll face even if she's freed, without ever treating her abuse in an exploitative manner.

Beneath that patina of penis jokes and four-letter words beats a weak and sentimental heart that fails to deliver the film's promise of raucous fun, instead wasting a talented cast of comediennes on cliche platitudes on motherhood.
A hot mess of random references, clashing styles and recycled gags babbling at high speed like a kid on a sugar rush.
It takes a callused soul not to dread the inevitable, and it takes an exceptional film to earn that discomfort from its audience. This film is not exceptional.
For all the tedium of the work before William, "The Witness" is a riveting deconstruction of a decades-old media narrative.

What was meant at the start to be a humorous fluff piece about dudes who tickle each other for fun and profit turns into a mission: To find and reveal the elusive czar of this underground tickling empire and to expose its true intentions.
"Raiders!" is as sloppy and imperfect as the kids' shot-for-shot remake, but it has much the same charm.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This one at least seems to know it's stupid and the story, incomprehensible as it is, offers more opportunity for levity, which you sorely need in a movie with a cartoon warthog picking its nose.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For three-quarters of its running time, "Dheepan" feels like something special.
I predict that within a decade, "Mother's and Daughters" will be mandatory viewing at film schools across the country. There are precious few such perfect examples of how not to make a film.
It's never a boring film to look at, but it is often a tiring one.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's so elliptical in its approach that there's no love for anyone, or anything, outside of beauty. It can be admired - greatly, even - but it can't be felt.
Calvin's Barbershop is the same familiar comfort it has always been, to both its patrons and filmgoers.
The film's focus is too easily distracted by celebrity and turns less documentary and more fawning love letter to an industry already in love with itself.
There are brief bursts of hilarity, and they are all, without exception, owed to McCarthy's innate charisma and comedic timing.
These changes, rather than inject new life in a story told innumerable times, underscore what it is that works so well in other, better iterations.

The same effortless chemistry that made the comedians such ideal Golden Globes hosts is on full display in this broad comedy, given extra oomph by a wise and glorious R rating that opens the floodgates of creative vulgarity.
"Mustang" puts its cultural stamp on a story gripping in its ageless universality and gutting in its modern urgency.

Curtis' portrayal of Gen's ever-present, invasive mental illness isn't mere window dressing and lacks showboating. The camera hugs his meltdowns with an uncomfortable perseverance as he talks to himself, hallucinates and turns manic.
There is a grating sloppiness to much of "The Choice," both narratively and stylistically.
Austen geeks and zombie lovers will enjoy enough laughs to tip the scales in the film's favor.
The craftsmanship of "A War" is unimpeachable. Tight shots and jittery camera work give the film an immediate, intimate feel.
The action is bracing, the twists sprightly, but the sum of its parts sits heavy, like a meal that won't digest.
It may lack the bold, pioneering spirit of Disney and Pixar's best animated features, but it still clears some pretty high bars into the human heart.
It is a movie by believers, about believers, for believers, to the exclusion of all else, custom-tailored for private church-group showings.
While its audacity is laudable, the film ultimately has all the thrill of watching someone else play a first-person-shooter video game.

Sticking Derek and Hansel in a world now dominated by smartphones, social media and selfie sticks gave the writers plenty to lampoon, but it's squandered instead on the odd hashtag joke and Netflix plug ...
Generates little in the way of genuine terror or suspense.
As lifeless as a Masterpiece Theatre broadcast, broken up by pirouettes and pliés instead of Alistair Cooke's droning.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An exquisitely crafted and enchanting film that tiptoes gently between stark family drama and magic realism.
Plagues of locusts and planet-drowning floods are also heaven-sent, and would probably be infinitely more pleasant to sit through.
In terms of showing what Farrell is capable of as an actor and not just as a marquee name, In Bruges stands alongside The New World.
Just when Will Ferrell was beginning to wear out his welcome with his buffoonish man-child act, he dials it down to deliver a surprisingly tender and moving turn in the drama Everything Must Go.
A strange, stunning and surprisingly sweet Swedish film about childhood friendship and first love.
It's not Octopussy bad -- parts of Quantum are as thrilling as any in the 22-film franchise -- but it's a huge disappointment, especially after Casino Royale renewed 007's licence to thrill.
It's impossible to watch without having your point of view challenged - no matter which side of the issue you're on.
A rollicking struggle that, in the hands of consummate ringmaster Almodóvar, is a joy to watch.

It's too long and Nolan tosses in too many twists near the end. But it delivers ongoing adrenalin rushes, mental popcorn to chew over and a rich atmosphere to get lost in. And it's impressive enough to rank as summer's strongest blockbuster.
It's a treat.
Step Into Liquid reminds you of those proselytizing efforts occasionally released by religious organizations that preach about life transformed by spiritual awakening.
It is doubtful that any war movie on the large or small screen has captured the varied experiences of ordinary soldiers better than Band of Brothers.
Butterfly ballots and hanging chads become the stuff of great political intrigue.
Spike Lee's monumental look at Katrina is richly detailed and realistically complex.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An inspiring tale heard, as it were, straight from the horse's mouth.
It's heavy material, but Solondz shapes it all into an epic joke about the folly of living a good life.

Paul Feig's female-led reboot of the long-dormant franchise is thrilling, hilarious, lovingly crafted and the wild, colourful, giddy blockbuster this otherwise staid summer movie season so desperately needs.

Loneliness, arrested development and the slow disintegration of the imagination are all topics of interest to the directors, but they approach each with only a cool level of ironic detachment that becomes unbearable after 90 minutes.
101 minutes of pure comic joy.

What starts off as a light-hearted, quirky portrait of a "competitive tickling" competition quickly turns into a deadly serious investigation about the destructive powers of the Internet and the perversity of those lurking behind its digital walls.
A trip through his wild and hugely influential filmography is mandatory for any film fan, and that's just what directors Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow offer in their new documentary.
A buddy comedy that's pleasant enough without ever reaching the full comic heights that Johnson's casting implicitly promises.
Little more than a genre exercise that rehashes a wealth of revenge-movie themes and tropes.
Comic fans will be mystified. Movie fans will be confused. Everyone will leave disappointed.
High-Rise switches genres effortlessly - black humour one moment, dystopic parable the next - until it becomes its own singular, horrifying, immensely captivating thing.
With Civil War, Marvel Studios has proven, once again, that the world's heroes remain in good hands.
For a while, it's quietly meditative and riveting - worthy of the Palme d'Or it captured last spring in Cannes.
More precious than pornographic, a light and ultimately charming dramedy about your friends and neighbours.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film is filthy with nuanced moments of fierce, sweaty intimacy, all shot with a precise eye for detail. At the very least, it will make you rethink your next rodeo.
If there is any doubt that this country's young filmmakers need all the institutional support they can get, then Closet Monster offers the definitive answer: God, yes, please!
It's a delightfully cruel work of high tension, perfect in just how quickly and easily it gets under your skin.
Key and Peele are sharp comic actors, and know exactly how to prick and push an audience into a realm of delightful discomfort.
No amount of vibrant scenery can distract from the tired melodrama that engulfs the rest of the film.
A sharp dramedy focusing on the romantic stirrings of a lonely office worker, played with considerable wit and verve by the 69-year-old Sally Field.
Lacks resonance and a steady directorial hand.
A shoestring house-of-horrors exercise that just sort of, well, exists, with no real purpose or artistic vision driving it forward.
It's all delightfully fizzy, bloody fun - even if there's the teeniest, tiniest hint of sequel ambitions.
An enchanting and whimsical tale of the lengths men go to explore the unknown, the sort Wells himself might be proud to call his own.
movie_title: How to Build a Time Machine (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is, without a doubt, the most delirious movie to come out of a major studio in decades, perhaps ever.

Star Trek Beyond is much more than a mere refresh. Thanks to Lin's steady directorial hand and knack for visualizing improbable set-pieces, the new film is bold, breathless and propulsive, a distillation of the action movie to its purest elements.
While Atkinson's intentions are good, his methods are shaky, resulting in a surface-skimming film that raises issues without ever approaching a solution.

A twisty, cerebral drama that just happens to involve aliens, Denis Villeneuve's film is a truly beguiling take on both the sci-fi canon and what, exactly, a grown-up Hollywood film is supposed to be.
War is hell, but Hacksaw Ridge sacrifices that truth in favour of something far more insincere.
The final product is an uneven one, mired by stiff acting, predictable plot turns and some truly stilted dialogue.
Paloschi's tight direction and crisp pace further elevate the film, turning what most would assume to be a sob story into a triumphant chronicle that never slips into sentimentality.
It would be a refreshing departure from the more bombastic set pieces of modern Hollywood if it weren't all so lazily executed.
A can't-miss opportunity to experience some of the finest filmmaking of the 20th century.
Complete Unknown is the perfect case study of what happens when bad movies rope in good actors.
It's bold, captivating cinema, with a soundtrack that threatens to never leave your head.
While The Birth of a Nation certainly has a powerful and important story to tell, it is, ultimately, a story told with little depth or artistry or skill.

Part mockumentary, party black comedy, part action-adventure and part cinematic dare, the movie is a bizarre, engrossing creation that will leave audiences either delighted or baffled, though never bored.

Berg was the perfect man to unravel the tale of the doomed oil rig, a feat he accomplishes with remarkable intensity, ratcheting up the tension carefully and steadily to create a gripping tick-tock thriller.
Tipping, who also co-wrote the polished script, captures this unique mix of adolescent anxiety, urban decay and societal friction in a remarkably confident fashion ...
A thrill ride that's as terrifying as it is no-nonsense.
Portman ... paints a portrait of the Jewish state's fraught history, all with the confident authority of a filmmaker who is years beyond her debut.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's breezy and cute and will do absolutely nothing to sway anyone's politics. Which is exactly the point.
The powerful filmmaking duo of Chris Hegedus and D.A. Pennebaker somehow turn Wise's quest into a compelling and noble tale, no matter what your thoughts are on the views presented.
It's a terrifying, towering performance, and one that would normally lend Hill toward Oscar consideration, if only the rest of the film matched his talents.
It is all refashioned in just the right way with just the right level of sincerity to make the project seem like less of a cash grab and more an honest effort to entertain and enthrall.
Radwanski creates a visceral, impossible-to-ignore document of one man's fraught reality. It is creative, bold and even dangerous filmmaking.
X's strong visual storytelling skills carry the film home, and herald a promising big-screen career.

Meyers must have been truly in love with his story to carry it all the way to development. But for anyone else who watches the film, it will be hard to remember it as anything more than a brief, middling affair.
Sure, Jason Bourne has all the hallmarks of a story - there are characters who are involved in scenes, and those scenes indicate the forward march of time - but nothing here actually matters.
Both provocative and underwhelming.
The film might be pretty to look at, but narratively speaking, it is a disaster.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's cute, and some of the subjects offer poignant lessons on the power of artistic vitality, but there's little in the way of true depth here.
There's nothing new here that hasn't been mined, ahem, to death in other, similar genre entries.
The Final Girls is all smiles and winks, but lacks the blood to make its horror satire pulse.

Hell, I'm scared of simply sleeping outdoors and I walked out of the movie with just the tiniest daydream of strapping myself into a rocket and shooting for the stars (ideally with Matt Damon as my co-pilot).
Cividino creates a volatile, captivating and singular look at adolescence, wholly free of the sanitized antics of Hollywood.
We can thank Villeneuve and rookie screenwriter Taylor Sheridan's tight script, but also Blunt, Brolin and Del Toro, each of whom has never been better.
Whatever criticism you want to throw at Roth, at least the director stays true to his singular, repulsive vision: His cannibals-gone-wild tale is a work of unrelenting and squishy terror.
The filmmakers know how to squeeze a lot from only a little narrative, Mendelsohn once again proves he's the reigning king of ne'er-do-wells and Reynolds has never been better.
Whenever Depp is on screen, nothing else matters.
While directors Jonathan Milott and Cary Murnion want to have their laughs and horror, too, the film is something of a zombie itself: half-alive and bloody, but lacking any heart.
Zippy, sharp and monstrously smart, Mistress America is not only Noah Baumbach's funniest film, but the best comedy of the year.
Everything, even Alec Baldwin's tight and itchy turn as a CIA buzzkill, is mere window-dressing to Cruise's attempts to kill himself on-screen.
All foreplay and no, well, climax.
Not just one of the more entertaining Marvel movies - infinitely better than Joss Whedon's overstuffed Avengers: Age of Ultron - but a genuinely fun and clever deconstruction of the genre, too.
Attempts to explore the darkness behind the art, but mostly finds a man living out his golden years in peace.
Although the film is raw, intense and even beautiful at times, the queasy knowledge of how it all came together constantly threatens to uproot any artistry.
Whatever your thoughts on the film's central up-and-down relationship, though, you can't help but fall in love with the way Sadowski frames the scenery.
Furious 7 is incapable of being indictable: it's pure popcorn escapism, brashly dumb and knowing at the same time. Like its central muscleheads, the film is aware it's breaking all the rules.
Scherfig often doesn't seem to understand what kind of film she's making, resulting in a broad first half and a slow-motion creep-fest in the latter.
Yes, it may not live up to Fred Zinneman's 1948 film on which it's loosely based, but it's strong and powerful all the same: a film where it's clear the director is in complete control.
The world may never again witness Peak Sandler, but that's OK. We'll always have Punch-Drunk Love.
The film is an enchanting creation -- a showcase for Kendrick's rising star, but also a bold shot in the arm for the musical genre itself.

Moss films this tale of economic anxiety and almost pathological compassion with an uncomfortable intensity. His camera captures hushed conversations, spilled secrets and moral trespasses with barely a flinch.
Once Rufus Norris's film gets going, it quickly reveals itself as a vibrant, almost revolutionary work.
As the latest entry in the tired "found footage" horror subgenre, this on-the-cheap film has never met a cliché it didn't embrace like sweet death itself.
Thanks to Fassbender's revelatory performance, Jobs comes across as a captivating monster, a dictator in a black turtleneck who is impossible to ignore.
The end result is a profound work of genuine emotional heft - two hours of hope surrounded by the worst conceit imaginable. Miracles, even in a place as dire as Room, do come true.
Condescending, self-righteous and sloppy, Truth is simply a bad film for which there are no excuses.
Ignore, for a moment, the generic title and the laborious first 20 minutes, and you can appreciate this mostly heartfelt, mostly sincere comedy-drama about trying to outrun your small-town past.
This is not a film, at least as most filmmakers and audiences imagine the form. This is proselytizing, pure and simple.
This is a work of immense confidence, and the restraint Trachtenberg asks of his leads is remarkable -- Winstead and Goodman quietly excel in what could have easily been wild, loud caricatures.
The Devil's Candy offers a lean and slick homage to occult films, but with a knowing edge that suggests director Sean Byrne is aiming for the critical rafters.
There are chills here and there, but not enough to justify putting on your coat and braving the elements on the way to the theatre.
This is sociology for dummies - and even they might find Moore's points overly laboured.
A feature debut of startling confidence, Robert Eggers's The Witch is not only an excellent horror film, but also a captivating study in extreme paranoia and the fragile bonds of family.
The film's bizarre, gore-soaked premise actually manages to ease viewers into the far more uncomfortable topic of grief - after all, dying is easy, but living with death is much more complicated.
It is merely dumb when it should be knowingly dumb; satirically dull when it should be sharp; and just plain ugly when it should be, at the very least, aesthetically minded.
Deadpool is everything that Hollywood has raised audiences to believe heroes are not: crass, selfish and with a vocabulary that would have made George Carlin blush.
The screenwriter of The Departed aims for a statement about the perils of fame, but instead comes off as the poster boy for toxic celebrity narcissism.
Like its source material - a loose term if there ever was one - Steers's movie is a failure across multiple fronts.

Old Jerusalem isn't often glimpsed on the big screen, though it's a shame that, in this case, it simply serves as the backdrop to some rampaging CGI demons and half-baked theology about the gates of hell.
While many people make films like Anderson, Anderson makes films like no one else.
Mixes subtle politics and morality in an expert, if discomfiting, manner.
It's as if the film was designed to appeal to both my inner child and my inner snob. Both were left feeling disappointed.
A generic comedy as lazy and aggravating as its title.
The film employs and immediately squanders the talents of legitimate comedy all-stars Amy Ryan, Danny McBride, Jemaine Clement and Will Forte.
Helgeland uses long-take shots through boisterous clubs, unreliable narration and splashes of violence to create a drama of little surprise and even less impact.

Silverman delivers a knockout performance - any memories of her scatalogical stand-up act are washed away in an instant. But her intense commitment to the depths of depression belongs in a better, more focused, less derivative film.

A finely tuned comedy machine, a film that not only works as a standalone contemporary project, but one that will come to be viewed in five, 10, 15 years as a snapshot of industry players at their prime, and a handy guide to before-they-were-famous icons.
What the Pitts failed to realize during production, is that there is more to those beloved European art-house films than pretty scenery and stylish wardrobes.
A remarkably assured and tight retelling of the Boston Globe's investigation into the Catholic Church's legacy of child abuse and cover-ups.
This is all simply Malick being Malick - you're either on his wavelength or you're not.
A ridiculous, high-camp mess that could easily be mistaken for substance, if it weren't so irredeemably silly.
[Sean] Baker mostly crafts a tiny adventure of absorbing wonder.
This material might make for a sly, subversive take on the genre, but writer-director Tyson Caron positions Dash as the hero of his story, a fatal flaw.
There are no fireworks or twists or unnecessary frills here, nor should there be - this is simply perfect filmmaking from a voice that demands to be heard.

[Bryan] Cranston and [Kevin] Hart fight tooth and nail to keep the film as charming as possible, though, with Hart going to particularly impressive lengths. It almost works, until you remember it shouldn't.
An outrageous and outrageously entertaining treatise on cultural sensitivity.
The dialogue is paced at about the intensity of a jackhammer and every other sentence uttered ends on a twist of the one that came before it.
At times, it approaches self-parody, but that's just [John] Woo having some much-needed fun. The man deserves it.
The Square turns from a sharp art-world satire into something egregiously bonkers, a mish-mash of blunt comic beats and heavy-handed social commentary.
A shockingly poignant portrait of the jealousies that arise when the creative process goes haywire.
Whatever stabs at dark comedy, social satire and noir-esque murder mystery the Coens may have once been mulling with Suburbicon are only superficial wounds in [George] Clooney's hands.

Goosebumps speeds up helter-skelter in the second act and never loses its momentum, providing an eye-popping feast. Cool visuals aside, it's also full of intertextual content.
Maggie Gyllenhaal channels Emma Thompson on heat. No sale.
If you fancy indulging in pure, unadulterated silliness and spending a night in the '90s, this is a good bet. Otherwise...
A must for anyone interested in contemporary design, film and how life and work meld together.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film that will fill you with a sense of hope, and a glimpse into the realities of life in modern Hong Kong.
Worth it for the glitz and Wright's brave film-within-the-theatre idea.
Apart from the soppy soundtrack, it's very affecting and potent stuff.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Subtle and beautifully humane.
movie_title: Village At The End Of The World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, thoughtful, funny, fearless.
Boosted by a terrific lead turn from Riz Ahmed.
Rich themes, beautifully illustrated. But fails to wow.
Definitely one for middle-aged neurotics, but enjoyable all the same.
Nick Frost shakes his funky stuff in this likeable if unadventurous British romantic comedy.
It grows on you, afterwards, but is perhaps an acquired taste.
An obvious labor of love, the film successfully comments on gays in the military, racism, xenophobia, and sexism in a sly, entertaining manner throughout.
movie_title: The Battle of Pussy Willow Creek (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Grapes of Wrath is, in fact, the greatest master- piece the screen has ever produced; in it John Ford has established in vivid and inescapable terms the knowledge of good and evil.
It's a great shame because Sebold's book showed us a world of pain, loss and love. That sense has been lost in translation.
This gorilla of a film is blockbuster of the year.
While there's fun to be had at this new film, there were moments when I thought, like some of Indy's archaeological finds, it probably should have remained as a museum piece.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not enough scalps. While it's good and there are fun elements it's rather dialogue led than jam-packed with action.
The film is a fantastic monument to Jackson but it does us a dis-service by not giving us a sense of what made him die.
You can't get your childhood back but for one hour and 38 minutes Toy Story 3 gets you pretty close. Oh, and by the way -- your kids will love it, too.
The film works splendidly. It's big-screen entertainment at its best.

These Transformer movies are nonsense, of course, but they allow Bay and his team to push the envelope as far as movie technology is concerned and at least you feel get a sense of the shock and awe of giant hulking metal creatures clashing.

The entire series of Potter books and motion pictures has been leading us to this final showdown between Harry and Voldemort. It could easily have been a letdown. But the fight here between good and evil is more than satisfying. It's thrilling.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most compelling love stories in history.
Nothing can beat a landmark, classic James Bond picture. They don't come around all that often.
Somehow the final film has stuff to say about love, friendship and loyalty that works.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A five-star movie musical extravaganza that hums with the spirit of Victor Hugo's classic novel and the landmark stage show upon which it's based.
Norse nonsense, but great fun.

The Runaways is let down by its inability to decide where the story ends, but it will doubtless resonate with anyone who ever dreamed of quitting school to become a rock star.
Writer/director Colm McCarthy's vision seems to have been lost in the midst of entrails, muddled mythology and incomplete plot points.
Like many of the characters, the plot is under-developed yet My Son, My Son lingers in the brain and is essential viewing for Herzog and Lynch fans alike.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Realised through animated puppets it will inevitably be compared to Team America:World Police, a likeness that does it no favours.
Lukas Moodysson's approach to filmmaking was becoming increasingly experimental, so it is a surprise to see how conventional Mammoth is.
Created by a fan for fans everywhere, Eisener's film is simultaneously original and a perfect throwback to the blood-splattered movies of the 70s.
With an excellent, pounding soundtrack by electronic artist Vitalic, this hypnotic, mesmerising film has "future cult classic" written all over it.
As George beds woman after woman, with the specific intent of moving up the social ladder, the seduction is non-existent. So too is the hedonism and debauchery of Paris in the 1890s.
While well executed, Muschietti's feature debut lacks the originality and flair to have much staying power, though it ends on a high with an unexpected, oddly bittersweet conclusion.
Luis Tosar's performance is central to the success of Sleep Tight, a taut psychological thriller set in an upmarket apartment block.
The felling of the beanstalk is - especially in 3D - a dynamic set piece, but it is too little to elevate the film to anything more than mundanity.

Entertaining, flashy, and action-packed, if rather lacking in substance, Into Darkness represents a continuing improvement on the franchise, with interesting implications as to the direction of future films.
It's hard to not get caught up by the smoky, strobe-filled excess of easy money and ecstasy-enhanced raves.
Tsangari's female perspective shines a light on the intrinsic issues with masculinity in our society. In an absolutely hilarious way, of course.
A Syrian Love Story aims to put names and faces to the problems in Syria, making the film personal and deeply emotional. It succeeds, in every way.
Despite its roughness and lack of 'drama', Addicted to Sheep truly embodies the nature of the ob-doc.
The Falling speaks out to young women and represents that feeling of discomfort and complete bewilderment about their bodies, their futures and their minds.
3 And 1/2 Minutes, 10 Bullets is a highly emotional documentary, one that clearly needed to be made.
A Bigger Splash is a lazy, meandering journey which takes its time getting there, but when it arrives it feels worth it.
Krisha is a truly unique film, and one that I'll be thinking about for weeks.
Although a bit rough round the edges, I Know A Woman Like That will speak to women everywhere no matter what age you are.
movie_title: I Know a Woman Like That (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and tackling stories that are painfully difficult to tell, Parched should be at the top of your watch list.
As I Open My Eyes: an expertly woven story exploring sexuality, mother-daughter relationships, a country at war with itself and a young girl caught up in the middle of it all.
movie_title: As I Open My Eyes (À peine j'ouvre les yeux) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Suffragette is a fantastic resource about a period of history that remains largely unspoken about.
I Am Jane Doe doesn't quite work in some places, but it's a significant film deserving global recognition - if only to bring attention to the realities of child trafficking.
Risk tries to peel back the facade, but ultimately fails to succeed in giving us anything particularly new or radical.
Though it isn't perfect, it's the right time for this film. The UK is more divided than ever and we need to be reminded that there are people in Government who care about the working people.
movie_title: Dennis Skinner: Nature of the Beast (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What could have been a really interesting film with a unique narrative turns into a pretty grotesque film instead, with tropes rather than well-rounded characters.
Daphne truly is a fascinating character study. Emily Beecham is astounding, portraying a layered and complex character, and one that we rarely see on screen.
The Party relies not on gimmicks or CGI, but simple, clever narrative structures, witty dialogue and a cast of impenetrable actors. It's a true triumph.
Supporting personal stories from her contributors with historical evidence, numerical statistics and information from specialists - Brea's Unrest is the definitive film about ME.
Manifesto has some magnificent moments, and Blanchett does give an unparalleled performance, but ultimately it is a repetitive and cyclical exercise.
Prince of Nothingwood is not only a portrait of a unique man, but of the importance of cinema too.
Prevenged is a wickedly funny film, with a unique twist on old body-horror stories of 1970s and '80s cinema.
Freedom is a great work of documentary filmmaking: stylishly shot, narratively gripping and backed by string arrangements composed by Michael himself
Dunkirk feels like this decade's Band of Brothers, a film likely to be the launchpad for the next set of hot, young British actors.
All this whacky mirth, mayhem and lack of plot could irritate all of us over 25s were the team all mere meatheads. Thankfully they're not... they're a witty, articulate bunch.

Both silliness and sap increase as the film rolls along, but the big action scenes are handled well, and it never becomes ridiculous enough to undercut the cool, shaken-not-stirred vibe of its first half.
The film will leave you feeling exhausted -- it's vibrant, haunting and, I've probably overused it, but also overwhelmingly sad.
From start to end this film is just pure joy, a lot of which is borne from the fact that the original is so much fun that there's no point trying to lay those ghosts to rest.
Ari Folman's follow up to the impressive Waltz With Bashir is bold, daringly different and visually arresting, but it's also a bit too much.
It just isn't scary or clever enough and doesn't really gain momentum until a last minute dash towards a toe-curlingly obvious resolution.

There are a lot of decent jolts and pregnant pauses that build to an unexpectedly emotional ending - there won't be that much new if you've read the book, but it's still an intriguing premise all the same.
As 'yoof' films go... it's an entertaining watch and doesn't take too much investment.
The Rewrite tries so hard to be a knowing fish-out-of-water romcom, when it contains neither romance nor comedy. Any sentimentality or sweetness is completely wrung out within the first half an hour.
It's warm, charming and hilarious - I could have died from laughing.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I said of Divergent last year that it was worth sticking around for the eventual pay-off and that still rings true, but the next installments will have to deliver a pretty heavy payload because Insurgent is hardly likely to start an uprising.
The end result is a mish-mash of promising ideas lost in naff filmmaking.

[Disney] has learned plenty from Pixar's special move of subverting traditional perceptions of good and evil, mixing it with the love of a good origins story (à la Marvel) and with an added dash of wry humour that works for kids and grown ups alike.

To summarise in as few words possible: it is a film, it has people in it, the lighting is adequate and there's a monkey band playing Careless Whisper. Can I go home now and stare into the dark abyss that is my life please?

Trust me when I say that, for some reason, stick with the saga in the event that the sequels will all materialise, because the ultimate pay off when you discover what it's all for will be definitely worth it.

For a film that's trying to outdo its predecessor in every way possible, Rise falls a bit short. It still looks glorious, retaining that distinctive chromatic style and gloomy colour palette for that essential comic-book look.
While it won't teach you much more about love other than the perfect recipe for a deep-fried peanut butter sandwich, it will make you feel warm and fuzzy for a little while.
It's corny and it's predictable but there's an underlying charm that almost blindsides you, and its embrace of its ridiculousness is a definite improvement on its predecessor.

The action pieces are huge and impressive but it's all bang and no flash - that is, it's about explosions rather than exposition. You won't learn anything about the nuances of acting or the futility of war, but you may get a headache.
I watched Nine Lives the other day...it was awful.

Even a deliberately flat ending escapes criticism, highlighting the brutal naturalism of the piece. The Safdies are following the old adage of always leave them wanting more, which is exactly what you want after a Good Time.
It's charming, whimsical, and at times even a joy to watch, just don't think too hard about what it all means.

Incredibly, 26 years after its release, T2 stills feels fresh not only technologically but also thematically: threat of nuclear war, military weaponry, extreme ideology and the overwhelming sense that we're living on borrowed time.
Sultry and oh-so sexy, Call Me By Your Name is a masterful piece and romantic enough to win over even the hardest of hearts.
The pacing and lack of gore/information might not play well with a mainstream crowd, but Shults's drawing out of tension without relying on clichés makes for a fascinating (and sweaty) watch.
It's a bit bland and won't leave you particularly hungry for more.
Creating a gritty backstory for a 12-year-old can't have been easy, but director Joe Wright pulls it off with great aplomb, making it one of the most entertaining visits to Neverland so far.
Room still manages to be strangely uplifting, and there is light and warmth beyond the darkness if you can bear to hold on that long.
There are some genuine moments of comedy, thanks in part to the (deliberately?) clunky script and hokey special effects. Don't question why, just strap yourself in and feel the cheese.
To a certain extent it does work, at times being both mildly thrilling and outlandish, but is never enough of one or the other to really stick.
It's frustrating that a director as talented as Duncan Jones comes up short with his first turn at a big budget movie.
Brawl In Cell Block 99 will get all up in your face, your brain and your stomach and make you see Vince Vaughn in a whole new light.
[Andrey] Zvyagintsev overturns the idea of romantic redemption; not only is there lovelessness, there is also a frustrating inability to care for another grieving human.
Quibbles about the ending aside, The Gift deserves to be ranked among such films as Bill Paxton's underrated Southern gothic thriller Frailty.
Go home, Vacation. You're drunk.

The themes that Theeb explores are the clashes between modernity and decay, brotherhood and legacy, innocence and survival. There is little exposition about the colonial struggle, not that it is needed.
McQueen's persona has always suggested hidden depths, and the film successfully explores what can happen when a man pursues his dream relentlessly, with everything else a distant second.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful meditation on creativity.
A great romp and often laugh-out-loud funny.

Cottonfields and Crossroads marks another entry in what could be called Galán's Tejano music cycle, joining critically acclaimed documentaries like Songs of the Homeland, Accordion Dreams, and others.
movie_title: Los Lonely Boys Cottonfields and Crossroads (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Driven by outstanding performances, this beautifully nuanced film captures the allure of the titular city.
This intelligent, non-confronting film doesn't set out to change the world. Rather, it presents a compassionate view of family life today, without judgement or undue comment.
While beautifully shot, this film never seems to work as its characters are unbelievable and it shifts uneasily between comedy and drama.
While it's overly earnest in places, this inspiring story never veers into excessive sentimentality and is driven by a handful of great performances.
The Adjustment Bureau is not entirely satisfying, and at times, quite silly.
While the first half is a little uneven and the dialogue is occasionally clunky, the lead performances are strong and this ends up life-affirming stuff.
Sure, it's predictable, implausible and clearly skewed toward a young female demographic, but it's also enjoyable escapist fun.
It's a heartfelt effort and soundly performed, but it doesn't have the depth or nuance to sustain its long running time.
The locations make for enjoyable viewing, but disappointingly this bland teenage drama never transcends its formulaic approach.
While the least satisfying instalment in the trilogy, this still throbs with a slow-burning tension and provides an appropriate farewell to a compelling series.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In bringing history, literally, to life, and having as much fun with it as it is computer-graphically possible to have, director Shawn Levy and Reno 911 writers Robert Ben Garant and Thomas Lennon at least make [Museum] worth noticing.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's more original than any Hollywood disaster flick, definitely more authentic and thus very though-provoking.
The script aims for provocative, but, in a funny turn of events, probably hews even closer to exploitative than the usual horror hijinks.
It's not long before the utter relentlessness of the whole thing becomes exhausting.
Kobland's film is by its very nature phantasmal.
Thanks to Hiddleston and Hemsworth's impressive collective charisma, Thor: The Dark World is far from a franchise killer.
Eschews the genre's trademark reliance on facile, saccharine moralism in favour of the robust, no-nonsense and heartfelt nonconformity that runs through all the studio's best efforts.
The Texas Chain Saw Massacre loses none of its intensity as the years go by.

No need to buckle up, Death Proof is stuck in the slow lane. Self-indulgent and uninspired, bankrollers Bob and Harvey Weinstein should have reined in Tarantino with a genuine Grindhouse-sized budget.
At 61-years-old, Waters is growing old in disgraceful fashion. Avid fans will know some of the shtick already but nothing can compare to hearing it from the horse's filthy mouth.

Following Tarantino's Death Proof, Rodriguez throws his hat into the Grindhouse ring and comes out the clear winner. Impossible not to be charmed by its gross-out effects, bad dialogue and amputee action.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Outrageous, hilarious and shocking, this is trash art at its very best.
Mister Lonely is an exercise in transformation, both on and off the screen. Korine has shed his Dogme 95 skin but what kind of filmmaker emerges is not exactly clear.
More than just a midnight-movie classic, Martin is inventive, haunting and bitingly smart. Forget the recent Land Of The Dead and see Romero at the top of his terror game.
Jodorowsky's lyrical fantasy leaves Fellini and Buñuel spluttering in its dust.
We each decide where we draw the line, and while Hacksaw Ridge is an interesting film, it isn't so good that I'd suggest you cross yours.
Brigsby Bear is great. It's beautiful and hilarious and it has something fundamentally compelling to say about how we tell stories. Even if those stories are, yes, about dumb-looking bears.
Criminal is the answer to a question no one asked: "What if someone took the basic plot of Face/Off and made a dour espionage thriller out of it?"
It's a damn good time if you're picking up what Jonah Hill's putting down.
Despite solid craftsmanship and good intentions, Deepwater Horizon falters under the weight of the very real, very recent history it depicts.
A Cure for Wellness is haunting, gorgeous, and masterfully disgusting. In a strangely subtle way, it's one the weirdest films I've seen in ages.
The end result is a stellar ensemble wrangling heavy emotional beats and novelistic dialogue.
Where Donald Cried really works is in situating the audience firmly in third-wheel status, gradually revealing a more nuanced and toxic relationship between the two leads.
While some of the dialogue gets a bit clunky, there's a lot to like in how Elba and Winslet go about delivering it.
It's a chance for Chan to demonstrate his dramatic talents to a Western audience-which may take a bit of getting used to
The film shifts between a number of subplots and perspective, some of which are more effectively rendered than others-but when the film lands, it lands like a sledgehammer.
It Comes at Night balances on the knife edge between hope and despair, counterweighting the dire nature of its world with genuinely moving moments of warmth.
It comes off feeling more like promising studio outtake than a polished final track.
movie_title: How to Talk to Girls at Parties (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film both demands and rewards our close attention, but Haneke is such a master -- his framing so precise, his form so rigorous -- that it sucks you in by default.
The Rider marries the majestic vistas of the greatest American westerns with a deeply interior story of a cowboy having to renegotiate his identity.
Though such notes of grace make You Were Never Really Here stand out, they are few and far between in this otherwise grimly violent and willfully oblique film.
I don't know if it's worse than a politician without ambition, but there's something inherently dispiriting about a film with significant means and nothing to say.
Like any mean prizefighter, it's admirable from afar.
[Garrel's] detractors contend that he always makes the same film; his defenders say that's the point.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Jupiter's Moon juggles so many ideas in the air, yet none of them ever land.
Téchiné's film is a surprising misfire, especially because it arrives only one year after the director's masterful Being 17.
One of Takashi Miike's most lethal works.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A here-and-now valentine to what design wizardry Hollywood can pull off in 2017. At the same time, it does so in service of a tired tale full of repurposed visual tricks, storytelling clichés and big-studio concessions.
As a bit of art-house escapism, that it is a trip well worth taking.
If the second half of the film is more conventional, it also packs a powerful emotional wallop.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though far from perfect, this one part revenge thriller, one part eco-reverie, tied together with sumptuous visual brio, is the "John Wick"/ "Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring" mash-up you never knew you always wanted.
This material could make for a powerful work, but "Viceroy's House" is certainly not it. The film's chief offense is its bland inoffensiveness.
What the film lacks in narrative and visual subtlety it more than makes up for in rich human interaction.
A seven-layer dip overflowing with compelling individual ingredients, that, when mixed together, make the finished dish awfully difficult to digest.

Arrival has its heart in the right place. Who doesn't want smart sci-fi? Who wants to argue with a big budget drama about linguistics? And though the film is not more than sum of its parts, well, those parts are pretty great.
Like his camera circling the song about circles, Dominik is working a sneaky mix form and content here, creating a film about the need to create in the face of tragedy.
Tears of laughter and tears of grief are both in abundant supply in Asaph Polonsky's uproariously funny and heart-wrenchingly moving One Week and a Day.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Secret Life of Pets moves like a bat out of hell from frame one, though if you're looking for any kind of emotion you might be barking up the wrong tree.
Brings back the same cast of characters to do more or less exactly what they did in the previous films, only this time in sets with more sci-fi gloss than postapocalyptic grunge.

This two-hander about toxic-codependency from Romanian director Călin Peter Netzer is best in small-moments and insightful asides, but does a disservice to the relationship at its heart by honing in on one single thought and hammering it home.
Mixing story elements from other touchstone films and funneling them through his unique style, Desplechin has delivered a familiar if agreeable valentine to the medium itself.
Wolff cuts a fascinating if frustrating figure, and you wish the film would spend a bit more time teasing out who she is, how she lives, and what she sees in a bore like Max.
It's an absolute gem.
The film makes clear that there are no easy answers, no simple Rosebud that can succinctly explain any one person's character.
Rarely has the subject of human mortality been treated with such playful dexterity as in Nawapol Thamrongrattanarit's Die Tomorrow.
Director José Padilha's task was simple: find something new to say about the 1970s most famous air rescue. To that end, he ably succeeds at his goal, even if the project itself never quite soars.
Although linked, each chapter works as its own short story, each with a unique structure and thematic throughline.
A naturalistic portrait of a willful adolescent and his steadfast devotion to the troubled addict he calls mum.
It's engrossing, if (somewhat ironically, considering the open sea setting) dry fare made by and for stalwarts of the European academic set.

While Isle of Dogs is basically a fizzy, ornately mounted assembly of quirks and barks, the sheer artistry displayed... is so expertly accomplished, and so clearly fueled by love, that you can't help but grin.

Fifty Shades Freed ultimately authors its own most stinging rebuke, closing on an extended montage highlighting major moments and turning points from the trilogy. Tellingly, none of them come from this film.
Though the elliptical, time-lapse narrative never offers us much entry into Maryline's interior life, the actress makes it clear that she very much has one.
A thoughtful if familiar relationship drama, Outdoors benefits from an incisive grasp of its two lead characters' inner lives and an acute sensitivity for their many sources of angst.
Works better as a scenic picaresque than a perceptive midlife character study, but all the same it marks a promising debut for the Amsterdam-based filmmaker.

Working from his own script, Plante never resorts to flashbacks or overt speeches, instead allowing the viewer to piece together the lead's wounded backstory through uneasy interactions, allusions and insinuations.
Few narrative or thematic threads yield significant pay offs.
Without Glenn Close, "The Wife" wouldn't be much to write home about.
"Mom and Dad" has the same depraved verve, sick humor and berserk pulse of the "Crank" series, and what's more, marries all that to an operatic Nicolas Cage performance in full on nutzoid mode.
Though sprawling in length, the film is quite thin as far as plot goes...
... "Downsizing" is rife with witty visual touches and inspired comic premises but never quite comes together as fully successful whole.
Fatih Akin's film is just a solidly well made, straight-down-the-line drama.
An undeniably entertaining watch, "Suburbicon" stumbles when it tries to recycle effective old ingredients into something new.
The film is called "Victoria & Abdul" but it only ever lives up to one half of its title.
Though "Three Billboards Outside of Ebbing, Missouri" pursues a number of narrative strains, it's really about lost characters doing whatever they can to scheme their way out of a rut.
"mother!" begins as a slow burn and builds toward a furious blaze.
Far from being a whimsical title, Lots of Kids, A Monkey And A Castle is something of a promise fulfilled.
movie_title: Lots of Kids, a Monkey and a Castle (Muchos hijos, un mono y un castillo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For all the veering from one genre to another, neither does it feel rough. Del Toro's tight directorial control sees to that.
Fast, furious fun, worth a viewing.

An undeniable masterpiece.
Jonze's style s in his own inventive manner and, whilst the subject matter is certainly off-the-wall, the dialogue is spot on.
